I myself am allergic to any kind of opiates so I don't see the point of doing something that makes you sleepy and then if you don't have it makes you sick.  He is in jail at the moment and he is clean I think the violation of probation he had saved his life I really do.

name: Lindsay
text:
Heroin and opiate addiction have affected me in a few different ways. Not only am I a family member of person with an addiction to pain killers, I have lost my 20 year old cousin to a heroin od in 2013. I also am a Licensed Clinical Alcohol and Drug Counselor and Licensed Clinical Social Work and I work with people who are addicted to drugs on a regular basis. 
I have witnessed first had the trauma this addiction causes everyone involved. I have seen the heartache it has caused so many people. I have watched my cousin go from the top to the  bottom at record speed. I watched her try to better herself and kick the addiction, but the addiction was too strong. She should have just graduated with a degree in social work, but, instead she has been dead for a year. 
I now get to see her mother struggling with pain killer addiction and refuse to get help and doesn't care about who she hurts while doing it. I also get to see my grandmother distraught on a daily basis because of my aunt and cousin. It is extremely hard to be in my position, because I'm the LCADC LCSW and I should know how to fix my aunt  (atleast that is what people think) I know I can't fix it but it is very hard to see my family so upset over my aunt.  It has now come to the point with my aunt that for my own mental health have to cut ties with her until she decides she wants help. This is one of the hardest things I have had to do, but enabling her isn't making it any better. I just hope that people begin to realize  there is hope out there and they can move forward.

name: Tony
text: I've been doing herion the past 3 or 4 years. Being so close to Camden made it impossible to stop. I start using a needle and recently found out I have hep c. I came down to Florida for treatment in October and will never go back to jersey. Its sad to see everyone I grew up with shooting dope.

name: Kelly
text: I got addicted to opiates while recovering from a complicated csection and drs who were all to eager to keep prescribing. I've spent the entirety of my 5 1/2 yr old sons life as an addict. When pills became to expensive I was reluctantly introduced to heroin. I didn't want to do it but the withdrawl pains were too much for me. I ended up with a needle in my arm within one week of trying heroin. The hold it has on people is indescribable unless you've experienced it. I am happy to say I've recently detoxed, and am actively working a program to ensure that I remain sober. I am a mother of three boys who deserve so much better than to have their mother taking from them to support her habit. I'm a sister, daughter, mother, cousin, friend, wife .... And what most people fail to see about addicts is I'm a person! A normal, everyday person who happened to be cursed with the disease of addiction.

name: Mike
text: I never used drugs but my ex fiancee and mother of my child did and is now using heroin . How it affected my life and my daughters . My daughter grows up in the best years of her life without a mother heroin stole her mother and the woman i love . I got her off of it quitting my my job and carting her from out patient to outpatient clinic to clinic and aa and na meetings once i thought all was goo. In the months passing i returned to work to find out she was once again using so we soon split up in hopes she would want me more than the drug .. after a few months of fighting for custody i got it now she had to fight for me and her daughter but to no avail she stil has not come around . I picked her up on christmas eve to spend with us but she got arrested for having drugs and needles on her along with xanax . In the next few months i continued to catch her and cut her off for the saftey of my 4 children i raise . Again in hopes she would want us more than the drug still today i lost the battle . Hopefully she reads this and she might because she reads the news all the time and realizes this is about me and stops using for good so my daughter and i can have the woman we both love so dearley back in our lives .. thank you for the oppertunity to share our struggle
quote: My daughter grows up in the best years of her life without a mother. Heroin stole her mother and the woman I love.

name: Ashley
text:
Both my younger sisters have been addicted to opiates and herion. Their addictions started in the upper township/ocean city, nj area. My youngest sister started opiates in high school and still has addiction problems to this day, even though she has been through a rigorous nj state aided program called sunrise house in northern nj. She is now 24 yrs old with 1 child and another on the way. Her first child was born addicted to opiates and was in NICU for the first month of her life and kept on phenobarbital for 6 months. Even still after being opiate free for over a year a doctor prescribes her a medication which acts as an opiate substitute and allows her to take while she is pregnant. 

My other sister is a heroin addict. It is unclear when she started using heroin as it started with recreational drugs in high school and later turned to opiates then heroin. She has been in and out of several nj state funded program and has never completed a single program. She has over dosed and died on more than 3 occasions and come back. To this day she still struggles with her addiction is cons everyone around her into getting what she wants. The drug has even landed her unknowing landed her in Vegas as a prostitute. She was high in Atlantic city and a girl she met asked her to come to Vegas with her. Before she knew it she was on a plane all expenses paid and there was a pimp there to pick them up at the airport. She had no idea what she had gotten into until the high wore off and she was in an apartment with 10 other girls being groomed for the streets. It is fortunate for us she found her way home after 2 months.  She is now 27 yrs old, had never had a job longer than 2 weeks and lives at home with our mother. She has ripped our family apart and steals anything and everything.

name: Sally
text:
I am a parent of 2 sons that were heroin addicts.  It has been hell for my entire family for the past 10+ years and I still struggle with the trust and the worry every single day.  I believe they are both clean now and they did it on their own, one had to because he was in jail and the other one had no insurance and we had tried getting him help by calling all kind of places asking for help but were turned away.  He was told once that he would get county help but after 5 days of detox they kick him out to say they had no beds for him to get any additional help.  He is the one who really needs it still the most now, I see him struggling the most each day, I believe he has mental issues as well, like depression.  I really think what got them clean is the love of family and the fact that we would not give up on them got them through it. It is very hard for them to get jobs since no one wants to hire them with a record. I think the laws are going to have to change on that as well since there are so many more being arrested each day for drugs.
As I have stated I am 62 years old and the money that we had used to try and get them help is horrible, I don't think I will ever see retirement. The one was in rehab 3 times so you can imagine how much that cost us. Besides the fact that people who have no one who is involved with any kind of addiction don't understand what you are going through, they are usually the first who will judge you or make negative comments about you and your family.  I have lost so called friends over this and I know my boys have been judge by people who don't even know them.  They were good kids their whole life they were the kind of kids who were never in trouble in school who got alone with others and I am sure there are so many others out there who are the same as my kids.  It is so sad that we are losing these kids to something so horrible and no body knows what to do.   I don't think putting these kids in jail is the answer, at least for my son he got no help being in there.  No education, no counseling, no rehab at all. We really need education on how bad these drugs are and we need to tell them early in our schools and in our communities.  I think we need to try and get some of our kids who were able to get clean back into the schools and let them talk to our kids and tell them how bad it is for them and how easy it is to get hooked on this horrible drug.  Sometimes kids relate better to kids.

name: Meg
text:
I was addicted to heroin from age 19 to 25.  I grew up in a normal family with loving parents.  I was always very insecure and quiet.  I met a boy and he introduced me to heroin.  I thought for a long time i didn't' have a problem, but slowly my life spiraled out of control.  My parents kicked me out, I was in and out of rehab, being arrested.  I ended up in a homeless shelter with no hope. 

Finally at age 25, I got clean and stayed clean.  I celebrated 5 years clean in May 2014

name: Jill
text:
My daughter died of a heroin and cocaine overdose on May 8, 2012 and my son, who is a heroin addict since his sister died, is now in recovery.

My son had been in and out of rehabs since 2007.  

The cost to the family: both financial and emotional has been tremendous, but the devastation, the neverending pain, of losing our daughter, cannot be put into words.

name: Charles
text: I was addicted to opiates since 2005 when I was struck by a car and they gave me pain pills. Pain pills turned to sniffing them. Sniffing them turned to sniffing heroin. Sniffing heroin turned to shooting that crap into my body. I would drive from Pennsville to Camden every day looking for more. I have been sober over a year thanks to the folks at Maryville Addiction Treatment centers and I haven't looked back. I still know addicts and I try to help them and I wish I could help them all cause without that crap life is beautiful.

name: Ashley
text:
No one wakes up one day and says ��_��_��_I think I��_�ll become a drug addict today!��_� In fact, I didn��_�t even wake up one day and say ��_��_��_I think I��_�ll get clean today��_� when I did. I got clean because I was spiritually and physically exhausted. My spirit had been shattered, and everything I had known since I was a young child was gone. I had given it away. In my last days using, I was running around Atlantic City with a guy I had met in my previous rehab, doing anything I had to do to get one more taste of that horrifying high.

The progression of my disease ��_��_��_ because it is a disease ��_��_��_ was a fast one. I didn��_�t see what was coming. I could have easily said I had a problem in my early 20��_�s, but I was the only one who didn��_�t believe it. I was in and out of unhealthy relationships that were based around mind and mood altering substances of some sort, and I was convinced that it was okay. It was okay because this is what people my age did. Just because I didn��_�t go to college back then didn��_�t mean I couldn��_�t party like a college student. Just because I had responsibilities like family and work didn��_�t mean that I couldn��_�t uphold them just because I was hung over or jonesing for one more. 
I didn��_�t start out addicted to opiates. In fact, as deadly as that family of drugs may be, it was really just my last resort. I was a vodka and beer kind of gal for the majority of my using, and eventually that led to the doctor shopping for Xanax. If there was weed around I would smoke it, but I chased the drugs that lowered my inhibitions and seemingly made me feel more confident. But then I found heroin. I found it and I loved it. That young man that I met in my first inpatient treatment center was helping me find pawn shops, selling the beloved rings off of my fingers, which were the last things I had left that were gifted to me from both my mother and my father before my father passed away. We sold a brand new laptop for a mere $80, and he got mad at me one night when I didn��_�t accept a proposition from a 50something year old man to go back to his room for a few $50 chips from the Tropicana. But, I was hooked. I was hooked on the feeling the drugs (including the combination, all of my drugs in my system at once) gave me, and I was hooked on the feeling of having someone to share my hell with, even if he added to my misery. See, he was street smart. I was na��_��_ve and easily intimidated. I supplied the goods to get the money, and he supplied the courage to walk up to a stranger and ask where the good dope was.

In late February of 2011, I found myself in a hospital. I didn��_�t know where my car was. I didn��_�t know where my clothes were. I had two phones, and I didn��_�t know where those had gone, either. I told the hospital I wanted to kill myself ��_��_��_ not because I really did, but I knew that those were the magic words I needed to say in order to get a warm blanket and a piece of bologna between two pieces of defrosted white bread. I left that hospital and went home to my mother, who was already packing my bags for me and barely had a word to say to me. The last phone call she got from me, all she could hear were the noises of cars passing and honking along a highway ��_��_��_ there was no voice on the other end, and her imagination assured her that her worst fear had come true. She had believed with every piece of her that I was dead. She had the Atlantic City police looking for me, and I don��_�t know who the detective was that was helping her find me, but she speaks of him often and frequently says how she would love to thank him for his efforts and kindness during those terrifying few days.

I finally checked into a wonderful detox center, not because I wanted to, but because I finally understood that it was either continue running on the streets of Atlantic City, die, or stop fighting what was good for me. I decided that maybe detox would be a good temporary fix. Warm meals, cozy beds and protection from the brutal February weather. I told my counselor there that I wanted to go somewhere that was spiritually based. He quickly made a phone call to a treatment center in Florida, and within a day I was on a plane. I figured, if anything, it would be a nice vacation. 

As time went on in that treatment center, I was forced to face the consequences of the decisions that my disease had led me to. I had hurt my mother, and my two older siblings. I��_�m sure when my father was alive it pained him to see me the way that I was, and I��_�m more sure that it pained him to see what I was putting my mother through. When I went to Florida, she had recently been told that her breast cancer was in remission. When my mind cleared, I realized that while she was going through not only chemotherapy and radiation, but the aftermath of the devastation of losing her husband of 32 years, I was putting her through more hell than any of those things combined. All this woman wanted was a break, and she sure as hell deserved one. Me going away was not only the best thing for me, but the best thing for her.

I stayed in Florida for a little under 9 months. I went to a place called Transformations Treatment center, then I went to a halfway house combined with a wonderful outpatient called the Recovery Associates of the Palm Beaches. This treatment plan for me was intense, but it opened my eyes to how amazing life could be. I was having fun, making friends and enjoying my newfound freedom. What people don��_�t understand is that you can lock drug addicts up all you want, you can call them a ��_��_��_menace to society��_� until you��_�re blue in the face, and you can criticize their characthers and their families as much as you want, saying things like ��_��_��_it��_�s such a shame, she had so much potential��_�, but at the end of the day there is nothing more hellish than being trapped in the vicious cycle of drug dependence. I can assure anyone who has not done their homework that it is NOT about willpower. It is not about just putting the drug down and moving on with life. It��_�s not about going through ��_��_��_phases��_� or wondering when that addict will ��_��_��_snap out of it. It��_�s about realizing that addiction in and of itself is a prison. It��_�s torture. It��_�s a disease that I wouldn��_�t wish upon my worst enemy.

Flash forward to over 3 years later. I have stayed clean through working the program of a fellowship of my choice, which is available to any and every addict. I now dedicate my time to doing things to pay it forward and help other people. Also, that girl that thought she was entitled to live like a college kid who wasn��_�t going to college is now in school, maintaining A��_�s and B��_�s. I have a plan for my life today, rather than a plan for the day to get over the hangover and search for some type of drug to get me out of myself. I have a wonderful relationship with my mother, brother and sister. I share a roof with my mother today, but we also share stories, laughter, favorite TV shows. We share a bond that people might have after averting a disaster with one another; which is, in essence, what we did. I have hope for my future today, and I maintain hope for others, as well. Don��_�t get me wrong ��_��_��_ I would not be here today had their not been consequences for my actions.

I wouldn��_�t be here if I had been handed the key to lifelong recovery. Recovery takes work, patience, pain, tears and time. Recovery is a process, but I need to approach it as a daily task rather than a lifelong one. It is such a wonderful feeling to wake up in the morning with a clear mind, able to move my body without the pain of withdrawals, and know that I have a choice today. The disease of addiction no longer confines me to a personal hell. Recovery from the disease of addiction has been affording me the opportunities to do things like drive across the country with friends, choose a major for college, and treasure the people in my life that love me despite my past. Recovering addicts have lived two lives, and are by far the most amazing, inspiring and honest people I have ever known (besides my mother, of course). 

I urge anyone who is quick to pass judgment on drug addicts and their families to educate themselves. This isn��_�t just an epidemic, it��_�s also personal devastation. We can look at the newspapers and obituaries all we want, but until ignorance regarding this disease is confronted and corrected, not much is going to change. A few months back, I saw Governor Christie on the news with Jon Bon Jovi at a treatment center that I know of in the North Jersey Area. That was the only time I ever saw our governor publicly address the issue of addiction. Our jails are overcrowded, waiting lists for beds in treatment centers are sometimes stretched out to month or two wait times, and the drugs out there are getting scarier. I grew up in middle class suburbia, as did many of the friends I have who are also in recovery. This is not just an urban problem. The disease of addiction does not, and will never, choose it��_�s victims based on their upbringing or environment. It takes who it wants, when it wants, how it wants. No one needs to die from this disease, and I am living proof that recovery is possible. Although I cannot put my entire story on to paper, I can say that I have hope for others because I, myself, am a miracle. The issue is not who is doing the drugs, the issue is that the resources for help offered to those who need it from professionals are not available enough. We are throwing the addicted into prison for a temporary fix, just to get them off the streets for a little while. They are stuck in there with the same feelings they had when they were using, and are released no better than when they went in. New Jersey needs more beds, less hurdles for those who need help, and more involvement and acceptance from the general population. 

There is no shame in being an addict ��_��_��_ we did NOT choose this disease. But, we can choose to do something about it. I am blessed beyond words to be an Addict in Recovery, but I am one out of millions of recovering addicts. What a shame, though, that recovery is not a word that we are able to use freely without stigma. Those who seek solutions to their problems deserve to hear from people unafraid to speak about their process with recovery. We can be proactive as a community, and we can hold the families up who are watching their children, husbands, wives and siblings slip away from us due to this treacherous disease. I urge those who are too afraid to say that they are in recovery to use their voices to help others. I urge you to break your silence, show the world that you are miraculous, and push forward despite the lack of education among those who are inexperienced and uneducated regarding this disease. We are living, walking proof that there is hope. Recovery is a lifelong process, and perfection is never attained, but we can change lives with our voices. Hopefully, someday, society will follow with their own form of acceptance, and lives can be saved. 

One of my many wishes for this world is for the ignorance surrounding addiction, which is held mostly by those unaffected by it personally, to disappear. For life to be celebrated rather than condemned due to the word ��_��_��_addict��_�. We are not bad people. We are getting better, a day at a time, with the help of other people who are just like us. 

So, society, step up and stop judging.

name: Loree
text: It's been an ongoing battle with are teen aged son,from missing items in are home to constant worry for his life.And we tried rehab but the staff just educates the kids how they have rights and they don't have to stay if they don't want to!!Unreal.So now we are trying the Vivatrol shot because it's are last resort,he will be 18 soon and that alone scares me,I am Praying he is done but I will always be a worried Mom.

name: Carolyn
text: Both of my parents were heroin addicts. They were never fit to take care of me. My mother was negligent and lost custody of me because of her drug and alcohol use. My father told me lies, stole from me and my family, he cared about no one but himself when he was using. His use of heroin and pills destroyed our relationship and eventually lead to his death. He had contracted Hepatitis C from sharing dirty needles. His liver was greatly affected. He was eligible for a transplant, but because he didn't listen to his doctors and kept using pills, he was dropped. Eventually, his liver failed, he was put on comfort care and passed away. They both had been through several rehabilitation programs and jailed several times. My mother had been trying to get better, but due to other circumstances and long time suffering and abuse to her body, passed away due to internal hemorrhaging and sepsis. Addiction is an illness and should be treated as such. These people need help and without realizing it, or caring, because this drug takes ahold of them, they hurt everyone around them.

name: Kelly
text: There's so much to say, first tried at 21, fell in love, in and out of rehabs , detoxes, and jail for 7 years, overdosed once, many friends died, was kicked out, lived on the streets, stole, lied, manipulated, hurt many people, seen a lot of things a person would never want to see, done a lot of things a person would never think to do, the last run I went on was for a month, didn't see my daughter , i had 2 options die or fight, I fought , I'm clean now for 2 months. Plan on staying that way I never want to live that life again
quote: I had two options: die or fight. I fought.

name: Anonymous
text: I have watched numerous people kill themselves with heroin.  One of them, being a very close friend/younger brother to me who was like a brother to my brother also.  I have two siblings who have both been heroin users and opitate users.  My brother overdosed, was rescusitated twice and in a coma for an entire month and then had to go through months of rehabilitation.  His battle with opiates seemed neverending and what we witnessed following his overdose I wouldn't wish for anyone.  I can still remember every minute of his coma from standing by his bed everyday in the hospital doing anything and everything to try to wake him up.  I can remember my mother at the hospital from 6 a.m. in the morning until they would actually ask her to go home and get some rest at night.  I can remember every minute of the night they told us he wasn't going to make it and how all his organs were shutting down and do we know how long he was without oxygen.  I can remember them asking us what he was on and we couldn't even pinpoint because what type of opiate wasn't he on.  I can remember seeing him in the emergency room when they allowed us in, they worked on him and at one moment he opened his eyes and looked at me and then the monitors went off and they threw us out.  Late that night they told us he was in a coma.  They told my mother he would never wake up, but we prayed everyday.  I knew he was still there.  When he woke up it wasn't like the movies or t.v. shows.  It was real.  He didn't speak, instead he squeezed my mother and my hand so tight and manage to squeel f*&* in the strangest manner ever.  He wasn't fully there.  He couldn't walk, he couldn't talk, he couldn't wipe his ass, he couldn't wash, he couldn't even feed himself, he couldn't do anything!  It was a long recovery period that affected us in ways we don't even speak about too often today.  I despise opiates/heroin more than my worst enemy.  I now have a sister who struggles with the same addiction even after everything we have been through.  She had been to countless rehabs only to end up in the same place.  She is selfish and unbearable because that is what heroin and opiates turn her into.  She is killing my mother.  When I say it again I mean it more than anything I DESPISE opiates and heroin!!!  Everytime there is another big drug bust that happens I gleam with happiness.  I can only hope they keep cleaning up and get rid of all the heroin and opiates that circulate our towns and are killing our loved ones.  They need to take more control of doctors and such since a lot of the opiate addiction has begun with that.  There has to be further research to find new pain medications that are nonaddictive and put into use more often.  It makes me sad for everyone and anyone who is affected by what is going on in our communities these days.

name: Patti
text: My brother used heroin in the 80s shot himself in 1982. His good friend tried staying clean and about a year after my brother passed he used again and shot himself while he was high. My dear friends lost their son and he was in  productions I co produced in drama club in Haskell school.  He passed away in may of 2013. His mom started a changefornick.org and I am now involved with her not for profit organization trying to educate the public as well as help fund kids who need rehab and can't afford it. She has well giving scholarships at lakeland high school.  We are trying to get heroin away from our kids off our streets and she hopes to eventually have 24 hour support for anyone struggling with addiction.

name: Michelle
text: My fiance is a heroin addict. He finally admitted it to me a few months ago after months of suspicion he was taking something. Personally I have never come close to even smoking a cigarette and when he admitted to me his problem I was taken back by what he was actually doing it made me scared and nervous. We have a 16 month old daughter and my fear is that this continues. Thankfully, at this moment, he has found it in him to stay away from the drug after kicking him out of the house and 3 types of treatments (2 failed). Heroin makes a loving and calm person into a monster. The amount of fights, yelling, and tears that have come about due to the use of this drug is not a life I thought I would live with the person I love. The itch and cravings he gets from this drug causes him to leave the house to get more and more. A couple of weeks ago was his last relapse where I caught him actually dozing off in the car in a parking lot near our house while mixing the drug with water to inject it. It's heart wrenching to see the person I love self destruct and as I've said to him before if he doesn't get fixed I will be forced to part ways because I refuse to raise my daughter in this environment. No matter the love that I have for him there comes a point where I will have to make a choice between my daughter and me or him if he does not find a way to get better. I have stood by his side through all of this and I think he has finally found a method of treatment that personally helps him. Everyone is different and may not take well to a certain treatment, therefore, I recommend that if someone truly wants to get better that they don't give up and look for a treatment that will benefit them.

name: Jen
text: Both my older sister and younger brother are heroin addicts. My sister has almost 2 years clean her addiction began when she was over prescribed pain killers after a car accident. Everything spiraled out of control and she eventually became addicted to heroin. She was in and out of rehabs for years and is finally clean and sober and living in South Florida. My brother has over 5 years clean and is currently working in a rehab while getting his masters to be a social worker. He is also living in South Florida, where he went to rehab and finally got clean.

name: Susan
text: My youngest son died of a heroin overdose last year at the age of 28. He was a sweet, kind soul who's life was taken away by addiction, denying him the many opportunities life could have offered him. His passing has left me and his family with such a deep, painful loss that nothing can repair. the stages of grief change often or felt at the same time: denial  this isn't real, he'll be coming back through the door, he didn't die from an overdose: anger  that his life was taken in such a way, so soon, and at whoever provided him with the heroin; bargaining  if I had only helped him to get clean (of course I had no control over his using), if I had only found him sooner to save his life; depression  this is constant and hardest to fight every minute of every day, my heart aches with the loss...; and acceptance  unfortunately, I haven't gone through that phase yet, it's even hard to say the words "he is gone." My only salvation is in helping others: going to Naranon meetings  talking with and helping other families who have an addict in their lives; attending G.R.A.S.P. meetings  for those who have lost a loved one to addiction; and by helping raise funds for City of Angels NJ, an organization that provides support to addicts by helping them find places for recovery and even helps pay for it if they can't. I pray for other parents and families who are suffering as I do; I pray for the addicts to want to recover that they find the help they need. New Jersey is in a crisis situation  an increase in the availability of drugs and in increase in addicts and not enough places for recovery. Something needs to be done soon or more precious lives will be lost.

name: Lisa
text: I was married to the love of my life. he broke is neck when he was a teenager and probably should've never walked again but miraculously he did. as he got older the pain in his back got worse from this injury. 5 years ago he began taking pain killers which to my horror lead to heroin. our daughter was 3 at the time. I was in a living hell for 2 years then I had enough and had to file for divorce, sell our house to protect my daughter and I. He used for another year after that until he hit rock bottom and got clean. we are working on our relationship but it is a daily struggle for me. I carry resentment and I feel deeply for anyone dealing with this. It is hell on the user but hell on the family and friends as well.

name: Brooke
text:
My name is Brooke Donegan.  I am a twenty four year old college student, waitress, daughter, big sister, girlfriend and friend.  I have been battling heroin addiction since I sniffed my first bag when I was seventeen years old.  I remember that day like it was yesterday.  My friend and I were driving home from Camden, I put the dollar bill in the wax paper bag and inhaled through my nose.  It was a disgusting smell and an even more awful taste, but my body instantly started tingling everywhere.  It was a warm, comforting sensation all throughout my being.  I knew I had found the answer.  I knew I had found the secret glue that I had been missing my whole life.  I immediately fell completely in love.
     I threw up profusely the rest of that hot, summer day.  I was sweating and I was so itchy.  It did not matter, nothing mattered anymore because I felt invincible.  I felt at peace for the first time in my whole life.
     I went to my first rehab when I was eighteen years old because I had experienced my first overdose on July 31, 2008.  I was told that a UPS guy found me on the side of the road, barely dressed and gave me CPR which saved my life according to the doctors.  I went away because that was the first time I felt like I might not be invincible.  I was scared to die.
     I stayed clean in Narcotics Anonymous for a little bit over a year.  I felt accomplished and wanted to be a normal college kid.  I started drinking again in October 2009.  I was successful until June when I accidentally got pregnant on birth control.  In July, I had an abortion against my better judgement and picked up heroin again shortly afterwards.
     I stayed high for three years after that.  Seven totaled cars, six documented overdoses, rehabs, halfway houses, geographical changes and nothing made any bit of a difference.  My mom could cry all day long and it did not matter.  It did not matter how many times guys took advantage of me or what happened when I walked around Camden alone at all times of the day and the night.  I still loved heroin more.
     I have always been a decent writer.  I've kept diaries most of my life and I am currently going to school at RutgersCamden (ironically enough) majoring in English, minoring in Psychology.  When I was high, I started writing in a blog because I felt so hopeless.  I was convinced that I was going to die and that blog would be the only thing I would leave behind.  I was shocked when people started reaching out to me saying that they had read my blog and that they did not get high that day because of what I wrote.  That was not my intention at all.  I have not written in it in awhile, but it is something that I refuse to give up on because it definitely has a special place in my heart. www.inlovewithheroin.blogspot.com
     On October 6, 2012 I gave up the fight.  I surrendered because I was 22 and my life was pathetic.  I was completely disgusted with myself and refused to look in the mirror.  I was so tired of behaving like a scumbag.  I am not naturally a scumbag.  I felt hope for the first time in years.  I got clean that time through AA.  It worked for about seven months.
     I stopped trying to stay clean and started living life.  I got caught up in work and I picked up a margarita one night while I was on vacation.  A week later I was back in Camden shooting heroin again.  I stayed high in Camden for three weeks again and decided to change.  It was the first time that I got high and I wasn't satisfied anymore.  I was alone and I knew that if I kept doing it, I would end up back in all of those dark places all over again.  Just for today, I am not willing to go back to those awful places.
     I have been clean since May 22, 2013.  It is the most time I have ever had.  I go to school in the same neighborhoods that I got high in.  I write for the school newspaper and volunteer at the soup kitchens in Camden to try to make a difference in the same city that almost killed me.  I am currently going through Hep C treatment, I contracted it from using dirty needles.  I will be on the medicine for six months.  I am saving for my own apartment and plan to move out in a few months.  I got my license back.  I've kept a job.  I bought my own truck.  I have my first boyfriend who has yet to stick needles in my arm and who opens car doors for me.  I have real friends.  I rely on Narcotics Anonymous to show me how to live without drugs.
     My addiction affected everyone around me and my addiction made me exactly who I am today.  I am a beautiful young woman.  I am a type of woman that I used to admire and think that could never be.  I am grateful for my addiction because I am so much wiser and so much more humble because of it.

text: At present I have 18 years clean from alcohol and street drugs, i.e. crack cocaine, heroin, powder cocaine. However, in 2006 I relapse using prescription drugs. name: Lynn
text:
Where to begin? Well i hardly fit the stereotypical heroin junkie. But i assure u looks can be deceiving. For the last 2 and a half years iv been living a double life. Nurse/wife/daughter/sister/friend... A cheating/lying/stealing heroin head. Its exhausting. A little history about me. I grew up in ridgewood. Had the all american childhood. My parents gave me everything and more! They are still happily married. I was raised with good morals, church every sunday ect.. I played sports,made varsity as a freshman, did every after school activity imaginable. After high school i went to college and got my RN nursing degree. I was in a sorority had lots of friends. I met my now husband in college, we got married a few years after college. I started working as a nurse right out of school. We live in an extremely nice appartment we both drive high end cars, i literally had everything iv ever wanted at that point in my life. That was 2 and a half years ago. 
      Starting in high school i had experimented with drugs. Smoked weed a handful of times, i hated it. In college i had moved up to some harder drugs like cocaine and mushrooms... This was an occasional weekend thing. Percocets were around and i loved those but again, weekend type of thing.  It wasnt until i was 26 a coworker of mine mentioned she had her hands on a bunch of roxicets which are known on  the street as "blues".  It perked my interest so i grabbed a couple. At first it was still a "weekend" thing but  it quickly spiraled into every other day to every day. Before u knew it my tolerance was from a quarter of a pill at a time to 3 or 4 pills being snorted at a time. When i wouldnt take them id be "dopesick" and i knew i was in trouble but i wasnt stopping it just fueled the  need for more drugs.  When my supply for blues went dry i would hurt. Id be sick irritable id call out of work in search of more pills.  One desperate day someone offered  me heroin. "No way"!!! I thought.. Then my shivering sweating nauseous aching body didnt care, it will make me feel better? Ok ill try... This was the begging of the end.  Once i started doing heroin that was it, i was in love. My savings went, i maxed out credit cards on cash advances, i stole from everyone around me.  One thing iv learned about addicts is despite our bad choices we are incredibly smart, im a master manipulator, and best damn liar out there. Great qualities to have right?? My first attempt at getting clean i had confessed i had a problem to my family and they secretly helped me do a cold turkey detox at home, it was 2 weeks of pure hell. I was clean for a few months then quickly spiraled again. I went away to detox a few months later. Well, i went in snorting heroin and came out shooting up the next day. Stints in detoxes and therapy has been my life this last year.  At first i was good at living this double life, i think i just got too tired and the need for heroin trumped everything i had in my life. I lost my nursing job. My husband left me, he cant deal with the lying and stealing or not knowing if he will find me dead. Noone trusts me. I have not a dollar to my name. Heroin has literally taken the life out of me.  I couldnt make plans to do anything i once loved because finding the time to drive down to paterson trying to cop drugs was my second job.  This drug is no joke. My life is completely broken.  Im trying to rebuild the pieces but  its a slow process, and one thing about being an addict is i thrive on instant gratification.  This is a battle i face every day. Will i beat it or let it beat me? Who knows...

name: Preston
text:
January 11, 2010.  I can not think of a sadder day in our families' history.  My stepdaughter, Alyson Amour, under the influence of heroin was involved in a serious motor vehicle accident in Camden County which resulted in the death of a NJDOT worker.  The sage advice "you have to wait until they hit rock bottom" was a reality for my wife and our family.  The heroin addiction had presented to us in 2004, and the system failed my stepdaughter.  Despite top notch medical insurance and a loving mother...a mother that never gave up despite numerous challenges, the system, as a whole, failed my daughter.  We encountered "rehabilitation" facilities that seemed more interested in insurance company revenue than actual patient rehabilitation.  Our family physician at the time actually stated "I don't have any patients with drug problems".  The criminal justice system is filled with incompetence, and we are now experts in dealing with people who actually don't care about inmates.  There is no real rehabilitation programs at Edna Mahan Correctional Facility, in fact, with the exception of Camden County Drug Court, the entire system seems flawed and filled with incompetence.  The happy story is Alyson's status today.  From my observation, the sobering fact that she killed a person whom she had never met was the catalyst in her recovery.  She has had to deal with a criminal justice system which does not care about drug userswith very little programming.  The facilities are worse than public housing.  The food/medical care is terrible.  However, she has quit smoking.  She is drug free.  She is maintaining an "A" average in college courses offered by Drew University and local community colleges.  She is an active participant in a "working dog" program and now has a skill set training dogs.  The most impressive thing she has done is participate in Project PRIDE, which marries at risk high school students with inmates willing to speak about their addiction challenges.  She is really good at delivering her total message, and is trying hard to make a difference.  To say that we are proud of her goes beyond words.

We are facing a similar challenge now with her brother, although the problem is prescription medications.  The challenges are noteworthy.  There are problems with the "rehab" center mentality.  Our willingness to be dominated by the pharmaceutical companies.  The relative ease in which we can obtain heroin/opiates on the street.  The criminal justice system.  The stigma that may follow her as a convicted felon.  The lack of opportunity that is associated with this illness.  Social discrimination as very few people understand the power of addiction, and the problem.

name: Stephanie
text: My name is Stephanie and I fell into addiction of heroin at the age of 21 I was born and raised in cherry hill, my family sent me away to college, which I graduated from Stockton college in 2004 with a bachelors degree in criminal justice.  I was a normal run of the mill kid, I drank in my teenage years but heavy drugs I never experienced or was exposed to until my early twenties.  My using began when I got into a relationship with someone who had battled addiction to heroin since he was 13.  Though he was clean when I met him, a few months into our relationship, he relapsed, and introduced me to the drug.  I didn't know that heroin was going to alter my life in ways that would take me beyond my worst dreams of what hell could be like, and make them an everyday reality. I started our sniffing a line or two here and there to using 24 bags a day thru a needle.  Everything I had imagined I would never do in my life, became regular day occurances.  A woman who was learning criminal justice in college soon would learn more hands on by being on the streets of Camden and in the system of almost every correctional system from here to Gloucester to Burlington counties for all different felony charges and misdemeanors.  The child my parents tried to raise to the best of their ability they watched turn into a skeleton and demon of their once sweet child.  I robbed from my family friends, and even strangers, stole everything I could until even they would no longer enable my behavior and sent me out in the world to fend for myself and my drug use.  my parents changed the locks on the door in the dead of winter hoping it would be enough to get me to want to be sober, only to realize days had turned into months as I made a new home running the streets of Camden, and living in hotels from night to night with money I made from shoplifting and selling it to different places for money.  My parents had spent many restless nights waiting for the call that their daughters body had been found in a ditch somewhere, and I was too selfish to even check in with them to let them know I was alive.  Heroin and cocaine were my only fuel and drive, I lost a job as a manager at a huge swimming pool corporation I worked at, and  I was no longer able to hold down a job for more then a month or two, either from no call no shows, or stealing from the registers and anything else I could get my hands on. I managed to try a few short term programs to get clean along the way, methadone detox which i realized mixing heroin with it, only made it more potent.  After 30 days of the program i had a bigger habit then when i started detox.  I tried take home buprenorphine shots, they would work for 2 weeks tops and again i was back in Camden.  What i came to realize is i wasn't just addicted to the drug, it was the high, it was the life, it was the ritual of using every single day.  My using consumed my life and was a full time job, i would get up at 10am and run around making money and buying and using drugs until 11pm at night only to wake up and do it all over again.  Going weeks without a shower, wearing dirty clothes, unable to rememeber the last time you saved a dollar for a burger off the dollar menu and having people staring at you in disgust.  The worse part is when you are using, you cannot see the collateral damage you have caused to your body, track marks on you hands and arms so bad you have to wear long sleeves.  Or black eyes because you almost got robbed in a dark ally at 1am in north Camden, by someone pretending to sell drugs, or getting a gun pushed to the back of your head because someone tried to car jack you in east Camden.  This all becomes the calamity of your life when you are using, and everyday is really a miracle to make it to see another day.  In a matter of three years I found myself on probation after catching 13 felony charges for credit card theft and fraud, a stolen car charge, and over 20 municipal charges.  Probation sentenced me to two years on their program, and still I continued to use and give dirty urines, I was continuing to shoplift, and it became so bad that I was literally spending more time in jail then I did outside of jail. After 22 dirty urines and 16 new charges, probation didn't recommend me to a program, they didn't recommend me to a rehab, they told me they were violating my probation in two months and a judge would decide if I could be reinstated or if I was going to do an alternate sentence.  I showed back up at my parents house trying to get clean for even a day because I couldn't imagine going back behind bars after doing 180 days only one month prior.  I begged my parents to send me to rehab, but here is the problem, i had no insurance, and i had burned bridges with my parents and stole so much money no one was willing to put faith i would stay anywhere they would put me for treatment.  the cheapest rehab cost 35k with half of the money needed up front, and no one had that kind of money.  I managed to convince my parents my using was cheaper then rehab, and it was no longer to get high, it was simply so i wasn't sick.  I was a half functioning skeleton just trying to get thru one day at a time by not wanting to kill myself from the withdrawal again begging my parents for just one more day under their roof and ten more dollars to go get better. i was arrested again and my violation of probation ensued, they offered me prison, and they offered me drug court because of how many charges i had caught in such a short period of time.  I took the drug court, and they released me back on the streets, i deceived the system again, squeezing in one last hoorah of binge using until finally i was arrested again, this time drug court was sending me away to rehab, since i was never officially given the tools to get clean and sober, nor gave my body the chance to clean up on its own away from the environment i was doing my using in.  i was locked up in jail 4 months before a bed was available at an inpatient rehab, i spent 3 months in inpatient, went to a halfway house for 4 months after that and learned how to live life all over again in a healthy and therapeutic way, learning why a child raised in the suburbs with a silver spoon in her mouth  ended up a full fledged junkie on the streets of Camden.  Drug court saved my life, the officers always believed in me they pushed me when i was ready to give up and go back to a life of a using, and i completed a 5 year program in only a year and a half.  I graduated in 2008 and just celebrated 6 yrs clean in june. im pregnant with my first child and i have a management position at a thriving business, although i wish my life would have went differently, i learned getting sober what it is like to exist in life, and i also have been given the gift to LIVE in this life, and i will not go back to that life at any cost.  I have seen more people in my life in the 6 yrs i have been sober fall into the addiction of opiate pills and heroin.  People like me that never used before, i have lost a lot of people along the way from using and overdosing.  Programs are lacking in NJ at a reasonable cost  heroin and pills have trickled out of the city into the suburbs and affect people from the ages of 12 all the way into adults in their 80's.  People are dying everyday and it has become an epidemic.

text: I began using heroin at age 19 while a college student at TCNJ. My addiction became worse over the next few years but I somehow managed to get good grades and was even accepted to medical school when I was 21. Before I started medical school I was arrested twice for drug possession and that dream ended. For the next two years I was severely addicted to heroin, working odd jobs and committing crimes to obtain more drugs. I was arrested numerous times. At age 23, I decided to get clean and entered treatment. Six months later, while still in treatment, I was arrested for a crime I committed 9 months earlier, and spent the next 2 1/2 years in prison. I'm grateful to say that I stayed sober through the whole thing and I now have over 5 years. Clearly I can't be a doctor, but I will completing my masters degree in social work this spring and working in the field of addiction. Things didn't turn out the way I expected and I went through a lot, but things are great and I truly believe things happen for a reason.

name: Nicole
text: On October 13, 2014, it will be 6 years since my brother overdosed on heroin. I will never forget that morning when my brothers girlfriend called me. I had talked to him the night before and they were supposed to come over and sleep over. That was a Sunday. I worked about 10 hours that day and to be honest, I really didn't want company. I talked to him about 5 times that day and the last time I did talked to him he told me that he was just going to stay home and watch movies with his girlfriend. I went home and make kielbasa and sauerkraut, watched tv and went to bed. I heard my phone ring about 1am and didn't answer it, it was my brother. I then heard my phone ring about 9:30 Monday morning with weird numbers I didn't know, so I didn't answer. About 9:45am I see my brothers girlfriend calling. I answered it and she was crying. I said "Laurie, what's wrong" She said "It's Johnny" I stopped in absolute fear and asked "Is he OK?" and she said no. I said" I don't know what's your saying, OMG is he OK" and again she said no. I said I don't believe this, even though I knew what happened without her even telling me outright. I then hung up with her and called my boyfriend and told him about the phone call. He said he would call her and he then called me back 5 minutes later and told me. I screamed, I banged my head against the wall, I punched the wall and broke down and felt this sense of loss that I never felt in my life. I cried, threw up, pooped (sorry), threw up, cried, stared into stared into space. I really don't remember how long I sat on the floor after that. Then I couldn't stand still, I was in a dream and I kept banging every part of my body on the wall to wake myself up. This couldn't be happening. It couldn't be happening. I just spoke to him last night, we had plans on moving down the shore, we had plans, WE HAD PLANS. In my heart I knew why this happened. I then took the Xanax and Vicodin I had for myself and flushed them down the toilet, but not before taking 3 Xanax to calm myself down. I never been through this before but I knew the next thing I had to do was make the phone calls. I called my parents, who knew already because the sheriff was already there. Then I had to call friends. But before I did that I had to go to the liquor store and prepare myself. I called everyone who was on my contact list. It was so surreal that I was living in a fog through all the conversations I had. I threw up again and again and again. I remember I kept punching that wall screaming no. NO! THIS CANNOT BE HAPPENING!!!!!!! I couldn't breathe, I couldn't eat, I couldn't move, I couldn't think. I never felt anything like this in my life and I didn;t know what to do. I drank and drank and drank and yet, I couldn't get drunk. I lined up the beer bottles against my wall to remind myself how much I actually drank. I was dead sober. The loss I felt was unimaginable, intolerable, numbing, surreal, unstable, it emotionally took my life over. I would just walk and stare into space wondering if he had come over, would he still be here? But then I thought, if he did come over and it happened in my house, I would of seen him dead. They would have had to lock me away because I would of went insane. For the next 2 weeks they did an investigation because at first they thought he was murdered. His girlfriend is/was married at the time and is "connected' He knew of my brother and our family thought that she or he had something to do with it. I demanded an autopsy but my mother didn't. So with this fight going on it took longer then usual for him to be laid out because of the conflict our family having over this. She finally agreed and it was done. Again, in our hearts we know why this happened. Now let's turn back time a little. Me and brother started drinking and using drugs at a young age, It was mostly pot as the drugs of choice and never really tried anything hard, at least that's what I thought anyway. He had lived with me so I seen what he was doing first hand. I didn't know that his addiction was that bad until he started stealing from me and my mother. I still let him live with me because he was my brother and I loved him. I didn't have a choice. He started doing heroin about 2 years before he passed and overdosed 3 times and one time on cocaine. I found him once laying on the couch and I woke him up and screamed at him that I wasn't going to his funeral if he died. He did wake up and composed himself. That's when I knew there was a problem and that's when i started getting scared. There were times when I walked in and the house smelled like vomit. I didn't understand about the vomiting until I started using Oxycontin. He stole the rent, my pay, DVD player and thousands and thousands of dollars from me. The only time my head and mind were at ease is when he went to rehab. he went about 6 times and obviously each time was futile. I knew in my soul that this was the way he would pass away, I knew it. There was nothing I can do. I couldn't help myself, how could I help him? About 7 years ago I started taking pills. It was mostly Xanax, Vicodin, and Percocet. It wasn't until about 3 years ago I started using Oxycotin and Oxycodone. I didn't feel ashamed about it because I didn't think it was the same as doing actual heroin. In actuality, it was. I was doing the "poor mans heroin" as people say. My friends and family all knew I was doing it and everyone came down hard on me. I couldn't stop because it was a feeling that I didn't want to end. i stopped paying bills and even stole from my friend a few times to get pills. Was I going to end up like my brother I always thought. But I knew my limit and those couple of times I didn't know, I finally realized why my house smelled like puke when my brother was using. For anyone has done pills or heroin, you know what I am talking about. The withdrawals were absolute murder and even when I didn't want to use, I had to because I needed that feeling to end. it was torturous. I swore that I would never make that phone call and get pills again. I lied to myself because I always did. The last time I took Oxy was about 2 months ago. The only reason why I haven't is because I cannot find them, not because I wanted to stop. I don't want to stop. I do get Percocets and Vicodin once and awhile but it's not the same. Even though I don't do them as much as I used to, I know I'm an addict.His birthday just passed on July 17th, he would of been 40. I knew I had to get something to get past that day.  took about 3 percs and about 5 Xanax, and drank. I was so messed up that I feel asleep while getting a tattoo. Who does that when you are going through all of that pain? For the next couple of days I was on the same path until I couldn't get the pills anymore.  I lost my brother over drugs. I knew it in my heart even before his body was cold. But yet, I continued and continue to use pills. We are addicts, but he lost the fight that I continue to battle.

name: Christopher
text: Opiates took my father away about a decade ago. While working he injured himself a few times over the course a few years. Each time he was prescribed pain killers. The greed of pharmaceutical companies is literally killing people, ruining lives, and causing undo anguish.

My family was scared of me, I had no friends, my only love was heroine. I robbed cheated and stole for my next fix and when options ran out I used my body to get the next one. I was miserable inside and out. I was okay with that fact that my once pretty face was covered in scabs and scratches and that I would die this way. April 20 2011 that all changed. I was living on my aunts couch and she had found my "set" and any heroine addict knows once your needles are gone it's scary. So needless to say I panicked knowing that my family now had proof of what exactly was going on. My dad showed up, sat me down, and cried. I've never seen that man cry before ... But he sobbed and told me that he refuses to bury his daughter so I'm going to rehab. No choice. I wS scared, angry, and dope sick. The kick was the worst part. I am now a mother and a friend and most of all my family who once stayed up worrying sick over me knows I am healthy and safe. I am forever grateful for that day.

name: Will
text:
Throughout my years growing up in New Jersey, many of my close friends have been sucked into the abyss of opiate addiction. More than one friend has died as a direct result of using, and several others are still in their battle against addiction as we speak. I, too, am suffering from addiction, and am in withdrawal as I type this. 

To an outsider, 90% of the people I know who deal with opiate addiction do not look like one who would typically be associated with drug use. Middle class, mostly white, good grades growing up, nice kids with good families. These are the kind of people who getting hit the hardest now, as heroin is coming out of the cities and into the suburbs. The problem of drugs in the inner cities has long been ignored by the most of the population in New Jersey, thinking of it as a "hood" problem, but now as their kids and friend of their kids are becoming victims in their epidemic, there is a lot more attention. There are a lot of good people wasting their lives getting high, living day to day, and they can't get past the trap by themselves. Once you get into an opiate addiction, days and nights blur together and time passes at the drop of a hat. You don't even realize how quickly the days, weeks, and months pass as you go about your day thinking about being high or getting high. Even before the addiction gets to that point, when a person is just using every week, or every other week, they don't realize what they are getting themselves into. After drinking alcohol or smoking weed, opiates just seem like another way to get a buzz, but before you know it, you're wanting that buzz more and more often, and by the time you realize how bad your addiction has gotten, it's too late and it has taken over your life.

I have been using opiates on and off for almost 6 or 7 years by now. Heroin for about 2. In the early years, I wouldn't think anything of doing some oxycodone on a weekend to chill out and get high. Over the years, I'd want to get pills almost every weekend and get that high again and again. I've also gotten myself clean during those times, and it was never that hard. Maybe a day or 2 of withdrawal symptoms, then an easy week or 2 or 3 of being clean before I decided I wanted to get high again. A couple years after that, after being clean for quite some time, I decided to go looking for oxy again with a friend of mine. An old connection for oxy said he only had access to heroin now, and we decided to do it. Cheaper, and just as strong, if not stronger (quality is never reliable, but cheap prices make it worth the gamble) as oxycodone. Since then, I was doing heroin almost every week, two or three times depending on the money I had, and I never really thought I had too bad of a problem, but with my experience now, I definitely did. Over the past 2 years, I've gone from doing heroin nearly every day, with some clean days interspersed, to getting clean for 45 days and getting over withdrawal symptoms before that voice in the back of my head whispers at me to get high again. It is, and probably always will be, an ongoing struggle.

One thing I've learned is that there are no happy endings. You will either die, get arrested, or if you do somehow get yourself clean, you will forever be shadowed by the addiction. Recovering addicts are always going to be recovering, for the rest of their lives, and they will always have the stigma attached to them. You can see it just on this site, how some people looking in from the outside see addicts as "lowlives" , "losers" , and "scum bags". It's not just more help from the government that we need to help recovering addicts, it's a shift in the view the public has on addicts that we also need. I have already written way more than I intended, but I do hope someone actually reads this. Heroin addicts are people, and probably people you know.

name: Sarah
text:
I got addicted to opiates on accident back in 2006. Eventually, like most addicts I graduated to heroin within 2 years due to it being cheaper and more easily available. Unfortunately I am not alone in this as both my mother and father are in the same boat. I went to rehab in February 2012 and had nearly 2 years clean before I returned back to NJ for.a visit that would do up being because the Christmas gift of round trip tickets was forfeited to go towards my parents habit. 

I wasn't rich growing up, but after my parents started their own business in early 2000, we were comfortable. Now, my car was sold while I was in Florida for drugs. Their business is obsolete, they've had two cars repo'd in the past year alone, their house is in for closure proceedings and they haven't paid any utility bills in 6 months all because of a stupid wax baggie. Attempting to get treatment has been nearly impossible with my mom being om on a waiting list for several rehabs for over 2 months. I've had my slip ups since being home, but with the constant supply of drugs in the house things could certainly be worse for me. But I've seen irresponsible money hungry doctors blindly prescribe monstrous amounts of potent opiates for ailments that can be cured by Tylenol (if there are any present at all) and then cut people off like it's nothing when either the heat gets to turned up on them or if they feel that their patient is too reliant. I've seen people do horrible things to those that they love just to avoid being sick. Heroin has ruined my family's lives and there's no sign of it getting better anytime soon.

name: Dawn
text: At 40 years old , I never thought I would be planning funeral arrangements for my 36 year old nephew. But here I am, he passed away this past Saturday from an accidental overdose. While we are unsure of the final drug use , heroin was his drug of choice. Last October we found him in a hospital in a coma after being missing for 3 days. We traveled everyday for 2 weeks to be at his side all day.  Once he was out of the coma, and into Rehab he was given a choice to leave. Just like many other addicts, he left. My nephew would have given the shirt of his back to someone in need. We were extremely close and in his short life, I watched him become someone I hardly knew.  He would move from NJ to FL back and forth. He always found a source. He struggled with addiction for many many years. You think walking away and not helping them will make them realize... It doesn't. So here I am trying to fundraise for a funeral for someone who should be enjoying life, with a family and a bright future. Thanks to heroin, and various other prescription and non prescription drugs, my children no longer get to see their Cousin, my Sister no longer gets time with her Son, my Mother will never be able to make potato pancakes for her Grandson, and I will forever remember the beautiful blue eyed, blonde haired kid that loved everyone!

name: Sam
text: My brother became addicted to heroin while as a young adult and was fortunate to overcome this battle with the help of the Morris County Drug Court program. While being raised by a single mother, his addiction began after dropping out of high school and grew into an epidemic. Violence and stealing ensued, even from his closest family members. It wasn't until he was arrested by law enforcement (turned in by a family member), admitted into a halfway house from the MCDC program and given counseling was he able to turn his life around. The stories and examples that were shared in the house during that valuable time gave my brother a sense of hope, worth and will to overcome his problems. It wasn't easy but after 6 years in the program (included drug tests every week, calls from probation officer, regular court appearances while his license was suspended, etc), he was able to graduate from it. He received his GED, was able to learn a skill, worked his way up into a great job and now has a beautiful family raising two children. The one constant over the years was a very supportive family and friends who cared for his well being. It's all in the past now but we still haven't forgot that terrible time and reminded us that it can happen to anyone regardless of socioeconomic status. We're still very proud of what he overcame and his willingness to help others who are caught in the toughest drug plight.

name: Ameen
text: I am a recovering addict, my sobriety date is May 10th of this year. I was a high school and collegiate athlete. Unfortunately my playing days were cut short, as I needed my knee operated on. Sports, specifically soccer was everything to me and as soon as I knew I wasn't going to be able to continue playing I turned to my prescription drugs as a get away. Sports were something that I did for my entire life, since childhood and so it impacted me a great deal. Once I became dependant on the pills, I started making the transition to heroin because for me my addiction was progressing and I couldn't afford the pills so it was cheaper for me to make the switch. But like any other disease, my addiction got the best of me as I nearly got into tons of legal problems and was losing the people who were dearest to me. That's beside the fact that I lost many friends and acquaintances along the way. One thing I must say, is through a strong support system which was my family who never gave up on me and always so the great deal of potential I had ( that throughout my active addiction I no longer saw) they helped get me into a treatment facility overseas. Which the help of the facility and my desire to get my life back on track, today I am blessed to be able to still achieve what ever it is I want to do in life. Today I have the choice to stay drug free, and I am thankful each and every day that I was truly tested, but now I acknowledge that adversity only makes one stronger.

name: Erika
text:
I met my best friend in Kindergarten. We have been friends for over 20 years. She got her  nursing degree about 5 years ago. She was doing great, had her own place, full custody of her son, we would see each other almost every weekend, then..... she met him. He seemed like a nice guy, typical hippie type, down to earth, easy to talk to.. He introduced her to opiates. At some point she was going to three different doctors in the area to get percocets to feed her new habit. Then she started stealing percocets from her patients and that's when she lost her nursing license and everything was a spiral from that point. Percocets were to expensive so she started using Heroin. I knew she had a problem but I would NEVER expect Heroin.. Apparently she was using for about a year, our visit were less and less, I would get calls in the middle of the night of her sobbing, we would make plans but there was always an excuse. Her parents found out and she went to Rehab out of state, she came back looking fresh, vibrant, Alive! But unfortunately that didn't last long, I kept telling her that she should go to her Aunts in upstate NY just to be out of the area but she wanted to be close to her son. Today, according to her (users become extremely good liars and I just cant trust her yet), she goes to a methadone clinic everyday which is also very very expensive, and lives in the Poconos area, her son stays with his Dad. We talk once in awhile but its not the same. She is lucky to be alive but lost EVERYTHING she worked SO hard for. 
I miss my best friend. :(

name: Jen
text: I am a recovering opiate/prescription pill user. It started in 2007 when I injured my back and was given Percocet. From there it turned into a weekend thing to party and have fun. Before I knew it, I needed them all day everyday or I was sick and couldn't function. I lost my job and all motivation to live a normal life. Although things were bad at this point, on October 29, 2012 my home was flooded by hurricane sandy and I lost everything as well as both my parents being diagnosed with cancer. that is when everything really spun out of control, I turned to pills to numb the pain, confusion and repercussions of the damage. About 5 months after the storm I woke up one day and had had enough. I wanted to be a functioning part of society and start crawling my way out of the hole I had dug myself into. I wanted to stop hurting myself and the people around me. I found an excellent Dr who suggested I start Suboxone Treatment. Although I am still recovering, my life has started to come back, I have the motivation to live. Although the treatment is expensive, it's worth it's weight in gold!

text: My mom was a heroin addict and it has forever changed my life in positive and negative ways. Due to her addiction she was unable to take care of my sister and I so we went to live with my grandma. She raised us as her own and I am forever thankful to have such a strong woman in my life who has been an amazing role model and helped me through confusing times while my mom was in and out of rehab. I managed to keep a relationship with my mom even though it was extremely rocky. After years of battling her addiction she became sober and eventually was 12 years clean. What once was a positive outcome, seeing my mom clean and living a functional life after such a hard battle, she eventually gave in. This past month I lost my mom due to a heroin over dose. It was a shock to my whole family and has forever changed my life. I never understood how hard addiction was until she passed away from an over dose. Clean or using this drug has a hold on the person and every day is a constant battle.

name: Cathy
text: My son, now 26 years old, began using opiates/heroin in college.  He was always a good kid and a great student.  He managed to graduate and get good jobs but as his addition grew...so did his problems; loss of employment, rehab, jail, auto accidents, etc.  He's been in and out of rehabs to the tune of more than $100,000...I'm broke now spending all I had believing that the next rehab would be "the one".  Desperate, I drove him thousands of miles and many, many states away with the few belongings he was able to hold on to...and dropped him at a faithbased ministry in the mountains.  He's been there six months now and so far he's doing well....he knows, though, that he can never come back to NJ.  I hope and pray this is the  answer.  I hope that all addicts and their families find the peace and sobriety...it's a terrible scourge on our families and our society.

text: My stepson, now aged 30, had had various dependency issues since high school, starting with pot. While it may or may not be a gateway drug, you cannot convince me that is was not for him.  During his college studies he was hospitalized for a period of time and given Oxycodone/Oxycontin by the bucketful.  when he got out he was hooked and got involved in stealing from anyone and everyone living with an enabler until he returned home.  Shortly thereafter he went into withdrawal and we shipped him to rehab  the first of at least a half dozen attempts.  We found syringes and pills in many locations and lived wit lying and denial for years.  Finally after a longer period of sobriety he was arrested and did time for many other things, got cleaned up again, violated probation and got rearrested.  Last year during the holiday season, right after another rehab stint he relapsed, over dose on heroin and was dead before being resuscitated twice.  this was either one last cry for help or a suicide attempt. name: Cheri
text: Being the 3rd child of nine children. My father started getting high when I was 15yrs old. We always had a great life in East Orange. We traveled on vacation at least 20 times a year, but once my father had the habit I remember my mom crying and trying to put and keep food on the table for us 9 children. Keep our home ours, the bank would come and take pictures of the house, we were about to lose our home. I remember our car got taken, the lights off, my father would work he was a truck driver, at the end of each week he would tell my mom to go and get his check from his job in Secaucus, she would take some of us with her only to be told, he had already taken the check. She would walk back from that building with this look on her face that said it all. She would drive back home quietly. Probably wondering what's next how will she feed her children and pay bills. He made a lot of money but getting high took it all away. When he finally would come home to our big East Orange home she would fight him, I remember that. He would tell her please don't hit me I can't help it, I got a problem. He got high for years and I remember my mother telling him either you get yourself together or I'm going to leave you, he got himself together and he's been cleaned for almost 30 years.
