name: Kristen
text:
I began taking roxicodone ('blues' as they were known) in my early twenties. It provided an instant high, a means of tranquility, of contentment and ultimately, numbness. It began with small doses, 25 milligrams. But as time wore on, my tolerance increased, and so did the dosage. Within months I progressed from taking 50 to 100 to 200 milligrams a day. 

I was employed full time. My job paid well. But my paycheck that was deposited on Thursday was gone by Friday handed over to a dealer. The availability of the drug skyrocketed. It was everywhere. If one dealer wasn't available, there were three more numbers in my phone book who had what I needed. 

After months and years, taking pills was no longer a means to get high but something i did to avoid the withdrawal systems that plagued my body. Sleepiness, sweating then chills, runny nose, constant sneezing, loss of appetite, dramatic weight loss, and leg cramps that felt like shin splints.  

My depleted saving and weekly income were no longer enough to support my habit. I maxed out my credit cards. 13k in cash advances. I pawned my jewelry at one of those 'cash for gold' places. When that ran out, I swindled jewelry from my mom and sisters. Swiped cash from my parents. Stole my sister's debit card. Irreparably damaged the relationship with my entire family, 

I had become an unrecognizable person. For the moment I woke up until the moment I fell asleep, I thought of nothing but where to get my next fix. To get that one pill and stave off withdrawal. 

I wish I could say there was a moment where the light switched flipped on, but the reality is much more anticlimatic. I was presented with two options: attend an outpatient rehab facility or find a doctor who could help. I chose the latter. He prescribed me the drug 'suboxone.' It's meant to block the receptors in the brain that receive the opiate. 

Years have passed and I now faithfully take the suboxone but that drug has it's own pitfalls. 

It's marketed as a 'solution' to opiate addiction but very few people know about the side effects and it's own array of withdrawal symptoms that accompany it. It's trading one drug for another.

name: Trisha
text:
My now soon to be ex husband became addicted to prescription opiates after a back injury. They took over his life and since he is a health care worker RN he became totally corrupted by them. He stole meds from his job,and eventually lost his job without unemployment.. All the writing was on the wall, however his job of 15 years did nothing to stop him or help him. His behavior at work fit to a t as red flags for an addicted person. They were afraid of a lawsuit, thus leaving me to deal with this very sick and manipulative person alone with my three kids and no income.. He stole drugs and liquidated all our assets for drugs. Progressed to heroin and shooting up.  If he was high he was charming and convincing, however when he crashed his body jerked around, he sweated and would do anything for the drugs, I finally left him. 
       Unfortunately my young nephew also became addicted to prescription opiates, he sadly overdosed around Christmas and died. The scary thing is doctors wrote prescriptions for a synthetic heroin called hydrocodone, which is 10x more powerful than morphine, these drugs are heroin however the health care professionals do not call them that.  It is a terrible addiction, and I have seen all natural endorphin's made by body to combat pain and pleasure shut down. The body relies on the drug and needs more and more of it to avoid horrible pain and withdrawal. It is a sickness however it corrupts body, mind and soul, leaving the person with no conscience. People without a conscience are a scary breed. After years of living with this disease I left with my teenagers. I lost all material possessions however gained my sanity back. It was well worth it.
    Another scary reality is the social workers Division, and heath care professionals do not recognize this as a problem. They could not spot it and refused to look at it  even while it was staring them in the face. I had evidence of prescription abuse however no one would look or listen. If I could do it over I would have left years earlier with no contact. As I also became ill living a lie and paranoid about the consequences my kids and myself would suffer when the truth was exposed. Gratefully, my teenagers will not drink or do drugs as a result of seeing the effects first hand. We are left to rebuild our lives starting at zero. The one priceless thing we have is a strong support system, our church. So, one day at a time we get by with a little help from God and our friens.

name: Bernadette
text:
Heroin has devastated my family!  My eldest daughter died from an overdose 12 years ago.  She was an intelligent, caring and beautiful young woman, a graduate of Villanova University and 29 years old.  My son, who is now 38 years old had struggled in his late teens and attended rehab 5 times and was in 3 halfway houses over a 3 year period.  He went into recovery and was able to graduate college and become a teacher.  He lost all of that about 6 years ago when this disease reared it's ugly head again.  Relapses and rehabs became a large part of his life as well as jail and legal issues. He is in another rehab now.
Both of these young people never caused any problems for me until their drug use started.  Even through all of the worst times, there was never aggression but lots of lying and stealing.
I am one of the lucky ones because I have 2 other adult children who have never had a problem with drugs, and I know some families are not so fortunate,
Drug treatment is merely a band aid on a gaping wound.  I occasionally work in a detox as part of my job as a nurse and the treatment is measured in hours, sometimes with no available rehab.  I have discharged people who weren't fully functioning because their time was up.
I guess I should stop my ranting now, but I could go on and on.  I have seen heroin and drug abuse from both sides of the fence and it truly is  devastating.

name: Alex
text: I had a minor surgery in 2011. My primary doctor kept prescribing me pain medications, increasing the doses and eventually giving me stronger medications. I no longer could tell if I was in pain from  the surgeries or if I was in pain from withdrawal. Eventually I started doctor shopping, it's easier to get a script of high dose oxycodone than it is to get a script of suboxone in this state. My work has sufferered, my school has suffered, my relationships with my family is almost non existent. I technically have a chronic pain condition, so I'm still taking the medications. But every day I wake up knowing I'm addicted to these pills and I can't live without them. I also can't live with the pain. I'm caught between a rock and a hard place.

name: Sam
text:
We were together just short of ten years.  We dined out nearly every Saturday evening. We visited Atlantic City every other month or so. We had a partial season ticket package at Yankee Stadium (before it was torn down).  Then, we bought a shore house.  We spent endless days on the beach. Perfect nights at home grilling dinner and watching our Yankees.  It was perfect. I was  loved him unconditionally. 
        Then,  he hurt his back. Then, he was prescribed pain pills. Then, he learned he liked them. Then, he learned he needed them.  Then, he lost his job. Then, we could not renew our Yankee ticket package. Then, we couldn't dine out over the weekend. Then, the unemployment ran out. Then, the prescription ran out. The doctors wouldn't write any more.  Then, I was paying all of the bills alone. Then, I received the foreclosure letter. Then, I borrowed from my pension to keep the house.  Then, my jewelry went missing. Then, cash from my purse, pocket, drawer, hidden under the carpet went missing too. 
        Heroin is cheaper on the street than prescription pills. He stole form me to support the addiction. I confronted him. He lied. I suggested meetings and treatment.    He said didn't need any of  that. I then acceptable the unbearable fact that I was his enabler. Then the only realization worse than that, I accepted that he was never coming back. his entre persona had changed. He was repetitive. He was incoherent. I realized that if we could go to dinner together on a Saturday night, I didn't want to. He was gone.
         It was only then that I knew I had to leave. Without me, he would be without and the monetary needs to support his addiction. But, he would be without food and shelter.  How could I leave him like that? I was guilt ridden, yet he was the addict and the thief, but without my enabling him he may not have reached that point in his life. 
        So, I left after ten years, two years ago. I filed Chapter 7. It is a ten year financial sentence to make retribution for enabling someone I loved to become an addict. Two years later, after losing his home, his relationship, his livelihood,  he has begun a program to treat his addiction. 
         My hope for his success goes beyond my deepest emotions . I want him to be him again. The world lost a wonderful person.

name: Mike
text:
I've been addicted to opiates for 5 years now.  It started in college when I would periodically do painkillers recreational.  It was something I rarely did and usually only succumbed when somebody I knew had it.  When I graduated and got a job, I started using more often to balance the boredom of being out of college.  As time went on the addiction got worse; and as my tolerance increased my funds decreased.  I am the opposite of somebody who would use heroin.  I never thought I would touch the stuff.  But because the price is more than half cheaper, I went that route.

Being addicted to opiates has completely ruined every aspect of my life.  Even knowing how damaging it is, I still cannot mentally get away from it.  People don't realize how hard it is to stop, because if I go 23 1/2 hours a day rejecting the urge it only takes that half hour to mess up.  Medication has been helpful, but even that does not fully stop the urge.  

I hope this epidemic goes away soon.  I know for a fact the reason it started was from crooked doctors.  Some of these doctors have shady offices and accept cash to write down a script.  With these pills so available 5 years ago, it led to a bunch of young people with physical pain and no money, turning to heroin as the only 'better' alternative.  Rehab is an option, but it's not desirable due to my full time job.  It's a horrible situation that I would never wish upon anybody

name: Sheila
text: I received a call in June 2010 from my brother in law telling me that my sister was passed out at home with the kids when a neighbor knocked on the door. After she was admitted to the hospital we learned that she had overdosed on heroin. To say we were shocked is an understatement.   Nobody in the family had any idea she was using.  We later found out she was addicted to painkillers  the gateway drug  for years.  She lost her house, her children, her husband and all her friends. Her son who is now 14 is very intelligent but is acting out in school because of his anger with his mother. She lived in a beautiful home, complete with a new pool and lovely furnishings.  She drove a Mercedes, had time shares and wonderful vacations. She never had to work.  It appeared she had it all. Her husband provided everything.  Since then she has been in shelters, jail and is now a thief and a pathological liar.  She steals from family members and strangers.  When she could no longer afford it, she moved on to heroin because it was less expensive and easier to access.  She begs money from people on Facebook making up lies about why she needs it.  She says she has cancer, my Dad has cancer, her dog needs an operation, her daughter needs a communion dress. Whatever will get her money.  She has been in and out of various rehabilitation centers.  Nothing works and we cannot believe a word she says.  My Dad keeps giving her money to pay her rent; however, I do not believe that she is using the money for this purpose.  Very soon she will either be in jail for good or dead.  It is a very sad situation.  From Riches to Rags..

name: Amir
text: My poly substance abuse (mostly opiates) beat me down for 12 years of my life. I felt like a blank page , no words could accurately describe the mental and physical twists of the delusional reality I lived everyday. I hurt the people around me and was unpredictable and even sometimes dangerous. I lied, stole, manipulated and vanished into oblivion at any opportunity. It may baffle you when I say my addiction is the best gift I have ever received in life. Today I am grateful , loving , honest and continue to strive in my personal recovery. My family has re opened their hearts to me and I have reciprocated. Their is hope for us after all, I am living proof that it can be done. I have been clean and sober for over 3 years and am expecting my first child in December.

name: Tracy
text: It has affected our family in the worst way.  My 25 year old stepdaughter is addicted to opiates and, we suspect, heroin.  We put her in rehab during the last semester of her senior year of college.  She went on to graduate and earned a dualdegree in Forensic Psychology and Criminal Justice.  Since then (2011) she has worked mostly waitressing jobs, getting fired regularly.  She's been back in rehab twice, lost her drivers license, got into an accident without auto insurance, stole from her mother & brother and has stolen from her stepbrother, stepfather and me. Everyday we anticipate the phone call telling us she's either been arrested or in jail.  It's gutwrenching.

text: My mom (deceased) was addicted to opiates most of my life.  She had me when she was 16 and my older brother two years before.  She struggled with sobriety back and forth.  Clean for a few years and even got a job as a school bus driver during that time, but she relapsed. If you don't have insurance all you can do is pray for them cause you will not receive any help from this state.

name: Luisa
text: I have been addicted to opiates for about 11 years. First with the pills and then this last year with heroin. I am a teacher and luckily have not been in any legal trouble or have has my teaching license revoked. I just completed my first 30 day inpatient and then did a 90 day extended care program at Seabrook in bridgeton NJ. I actually relapsed in the extended care program with 3 other girls and was sent back to the inpatient where my insurance cut out. I am now currently home and just got accepted into an Oxford house in Brick and am going to meetings daily. It's of course a struggle since I have no friends that are clean and did not envision my life like this for when I was 27 ... All I can do is do the next right thing and do right by my family.

name: Fernando
text: Want to start by saying that just because I am a heroin addict it doesn't make me a bad person. I am a father of three. I have a 16 daughter that lives with her mother, a four year old girl and 3 month old boy that live with me and my girlfriend.  I am currently trying to get clean again. I don't know if I can or will. Lord knows I want to. Being dope sick ( withdrawal) is not fun. I have lied, stolen,  and hurt the mother of my two youngest children. Done some many things that I'm not proud of. There are days I feel that My death would relieve my loved ones of me. I don't ever want my children to know daddy is a "junkie" so if I fail at this I feel a dead dad is better than a "junkie" dad.The pain I feel just writing this is despairing. I Love My childen.  So so much. Hence why I want to protect them even from me. I have even stolen from them. Yes it is easy to read this and pass juudgement, shoot.... I judge me. But I assure you growing up I didn't say hey! When I grow up I wanna be a "junkie"? The mother of my children ( current girlfriend and mother of my youngest) has so much distrust ( rightfully so) that she sleeps with her purse under her head. It hurts to see that. My addition has taken so much from us. I do drugs because I hurt. I hurt because I do drugs.  And now a days I don't even get high,  I just maintain. There is no fun in getting high. Those days are long gone. My youngest daughter loves being outside, and I have Kept inside because was to high or withdrawing.  I am a slave to this and I hate it. I don't know where I'm going with this. All I know is that it is a soul snatcher.  Anyone reading this, I say this again, because you get high don't make you bad person. Thank you.

name: Thomas
text: My father was a heroin dealer/user.I always admired my father despite his lifestyle and wanted to have a relationship with him.As a teenager I can remember the destruction of the family unit due to my father's lifestyle and before my mother and father separated,my mother took me to the local jail where my father was incarcerated.I remember her telling me that she did not want me to live the same lifestyle.As a child I experimented with alcohol and cough syrup.When I became a teenager it became alcohol,pills and marijuana.then as a young adult I started experimenting with other drugs as well as alcohol and marijuana,soon after I was introduced to cocaine.By this time I was selling marijuana and cocaine with my father,who was selling heroin and using heroin as well.I was working a full and parttime job as well as selling drugs.I thought it was cool to be selling drugs along with my father.I did not learn till much later on that the only reason my father allowed this type of relationship was to get back at my mother.I can remember graduating from high school and not wanting to go to college and at this time I had a full time job at a liquor store.My mother told me I had to move out of her house because I was too much like my father,I was only 18yrs old.I found a basement apartment with no heat and no furniture.It was then that I got introduced to selling marijuana.I fell in love with the lifestyle and when my father found out he was upset with the fact the I was selling drugs for someone else.It was then that our relationship started in drugs.He told me to return the drugs to the person I got them from and then gave me enough money to sell drugs for myself.I remember the day he told me to come where he was selling drugs and I could make more money.Upon arriving there in a local bar he introduced me to all his drug selling friends and told them to look out for me,that I was selling marijuana.He also told them not to sell me any heroin.It was one of his friends who introduced me to heroin because he wanted some of the cocaine I had.From the very first time I tried the mix of cocaine and heroin,I had no idea what was to come next.I fell in love with the mix after using it one time.I did not know that I was going to go on a run from 1978 to 1995.I did not know that my life was going to become a living hell.That I was going to lose everything I had become a heroin addicted.Become unemployed,homeless have my car repossessed.In the early 1990's I became addicted to crack cocaine and well as heroin.By this time time I saw no reason to live.At the age of 27 I had my first drug arrest,my second was 2 years later and my third was 2 years after the second one.By this time I was completely strung out and avoiding the people who loved me the most.My daughter who I love dearly and my immediate family except my father.By this time me and my father had used drugs on a daily basis,sold drugs and went to jail together.I went in a outpatient program to keep from going to jail but I continued to use drugs.I received probation for all 3 of my convictions.In 1995 I went in a in patient program on my own where I stayed for 3 years.That was the work of my mother,I Love her to death for hanging in there with me and giving up on me.God rest her soul.I graduated the program in 1998 and I have my family back in my life including my daughter.I lost my only son to the hands of a drunk driver while I was still in treatment.Today life has never been so great.I am married,a substance abuse counselor as well as a motivational speaker.Every and any chance I get to speak to the kids on drugs or reach out to someone who is suffering from the disease of addiction I am there.God is so good all the time.
quote: Today life has never been so great.

name: Louis
text: I started using heroin at 16 yrs old. Every dream and goal I had for my life was pushed aside. I abandoned my daughter lost every bit of self respect I had.My whole life was about getting one more bag. I came from a descent,loving family. I became homeless,was eating out of dumpsters,picking cigarettes up off the ground, and committing any crime I could to support my habit. I spent 17 yrs of my adult life in prison.Everytime I got out I repeated the same things. I finally got tired of living like an animal so I went to a 12 step fellowship. My life completely turned around. I now work in a treatment facility, have a beautiful life,and I have 5yrs clean. I consider the transformation I went through nothing less than a miracle!

name: Susan
text: My husband has had a back injury for over 15 years. Rather than have the surgery, he was prescribed pain killers. One night ha ran out of them and started to detox in our hime. It was an awful night...an awful thing to watch. Night sweats, vomitting, involuntary muscle spasms in his legs, kicking all night in his sleep. With children in our home, Division of Childrens Protection & Permanency (DYFS) the children and I were asked to either ask him to leave or leave the home while he detoxed. I left with the children because he has no one that lives nearby. So he detoxed fully in our home with the help of his sister. Eventually he got the surgery and we have gone through all of our savings, had eviction notices twice and now, after his 5 months of treatment and hours of therapy for myslef and my children, we are returning home to once again be a family. Please wish us luck and say an extra prayer for my family.

name: Barbara
text: Five years (so far) of utter hell!!! Family living like prisoners in our own home.  Everyone locks their bedroom doors. Every night before bed we make sure we have our wallets, checkbooks, pocketbooks, money, and any valuables locked up.  My other children will only invite certain friends over that they feel comfortable telling them to make sure things are put away before they watch a movie or take a swim. Stolen credit cards, money, and even cherished items  gone.  How did we ever get here? It's a process that has evolved and seems like there is no way out. Everything is a bandaid.  You start off making excuses, bailing them out, "fixing" everything, yelling, fighting, trying to make their situations better. My husband and I fight (and we never do).  He's an enabler and I'm done. But through yet another process, you can't force an addict to get help (and he is absolutely correct), yet the family shouldn't endure this hell while waiting around for the addict to "hit bottom".  It all sucks.  I just don't want to live with my addict anymore.  We all deserve better. Recently started to attend a few NarAnon meetings and it's helping. You don't hate your addict you hate the addiction. Our addict is clean now, (about 3 weeks) and my husband and I are finally on the same page  we will help you during your recovery, but we will no longer tolerate this behavior in our home.  Here's hoping...
quote: I just don't want to live with my addict anymore. We all deserve better.

name: Lily
text: I lost my 21 year old son Nicholas to a heroin overdose on August 18, 2012.  Addiction took his life and ruined our family, we will forever grieve over the loss of our son.  He also left behind a 12 year old brother who misses him each and every day.  Nicholas was a 3 sport athlete in High School and experimented at parties with oxy pills, which quickly turned into a lethal addiction.  He went out of state for treatment and was clean for one year, he planned to come home and be with his family again, when he relapsed and the girl he was with was too afraid to call 911.  A senseless death, and addiction knows no boundaries and does NOT discriminate.  It is a disease that needs direct and immediate attention, were losing too many young people to this disease than any other currently or in history.

name: Julianne
text:
My best friend overdosed and died three years ago. She would have been 25 yesterday (8/21). She tried her hardest to fight the battle, but ultimately lost. No amount of rehab helped, no amount of love. I stood by her side because I knew that one day she wouldn't be around anymore and I just couldn't live with myself knowing I shut her out.

My aunt and uncle have been battle heroin and opiate addiction for as long as I've been alive. I remember having to take care of their newborn children at the age of 14 because they were both too high and incoherent to take care of them themselves. When they were living with my dad, they stole money and sold things that didn't belong to them. They had parties with their friends in their basement, leaving my dad or myself to take care of the kids during the night while they got their fix. During Christmas one year, my dads sisterinlaw had money go missing from her purse. At the time my brother was getting into some trouble himself so the immediate response was that he did it, but now they all know that it wasn't my brother; it was my druggie aunt and uncle. I looked up to my aunt and uncle when I was a kid, until I became completely aware of what was going on. The only reason I still answer their phone calls is because of those kids.

I could go on and on about this but I would need an entire 3 pages.

name: Marge
text: Addiction is no joke been addicted to prescripton pain pill for many years January of this year I put my self into detox and rehab I had enough one monday night my grandson wanted me to go to his basketball game and I was sick I had no more pills so I snorted a bag of dope that was it for me that night at his basketball game I called summit oaks and was in there that next day been clean and sober for 9 mounths I go to NA meetings 6nights a week out patient one night and H&I another so please any one just coming out of rehab please get to meetings it really works take it from me

name: J
text: I never thought it would happen to me. I was on the verge of graduating college from a prestigious school when it all began. If I only knew what doing that first painkiller would transform my life into, maybe I wouldn't have done it. I can't say for sure. But things rapidly progressed. Half a pill became one, one became two, and quickly I was doing ten plus per day. I COULD NOT function without them. I was fired from my job within months. School, which I was credits away from being done with, was not even a possibility anymore. I had lost all hope, my spirit destroyed, and dreams crushed. I was a soulless human being, simply a zombie with the sole purpose of getting one more. And when the little money I had ran out, heroin became the only option. Something I said I would never do. Within months I was shooting it, constantly getting arrested all over the state. Running out of gas on the parkway over and over again. Moving to Newark to live near my dealer sounded like a great idea at times. I did everything I said I would never do, and I did things I never even thought were possible. My brain was hijacked by opiates. A small painkiller habit quickly turned into a heroin and crack habit. My only friends were my drug dealer and my running partner. When I lost my running partner, the person that for a long time fueled me to keep going, I finally gave up. We were a team. And once she was gone I knew I had few choices left: continue going on by myself, risking more arrests, being "sick" every single day, or going to rehab. Many people in my town leave for rehab. The sad reality is that most don't stay clean. I told my father I needed help and he said he had been waiting for me to say that for years. I was beaten physically, emotionally, and spiritually. I was ready. I went away for 27 days, in NJ I'd like to add. I didn't have to go to Florida. I came home after 27 days, but not alone, with the Vivitrol shot. The shot gave me an opportunity to build a foundation in which I could start attending meetings and put my life back together. I quickly got a job, making half the money I used to make, and slowly I rebuilt my life. I finally graduated college and am now looking for a job in the field in which I graduated. I have 14 months clean and have a lot of hope today. I have lost four people this year alone that I personally knew to heroin overdose. I am just glad I made it out alive.

name: Mike
text: I have struggled with addiction for 10 years ....i have been to many treatment programs long term and short term been to many county jails and even in nj state prison yet I still find d myself helpless when it comes to the contents of that 5 dollar bag of her ion ......it has ruined my lif e and yea it still dollars it everyday I can't stop I wish I could stop
quote: I can't stop. I wish I could stop.

name: Andrew
text: The best friend i've ever had has crumbled to heroin addiction.  Good kid from a good family. We've been friends since grade school.  We did what every high school kid did, went to parties, hung out, drank, smoked some marijuana occasionally.  After high school we both went to seperate colleges but always stayed around our town during winter and summer break.  He started dabbling in pills here and there. Percocets, Valium, xanax, and roxy's (blues).  It didn't seem like a big deal at first. Then he started distancing himself from our group of friends. It was only a matter of time before he became completely addicted.  The pills become too expensive. If you can't afford them anymore you steal money from anyone or anywhere.  Once you can't afford that anymore, you switch to a cheaper option.  Heroin.  He has overdosed 2 times now.  Luckily he has survived.  Been to prison, rehab, and almost death, however nothing has saved him or made him stop.  I do not know my best friend anymore, I dont know where he lives anymore.  I occasionally hear about him, someone tells me they ran into him from time to time.  Last I heard he moved out of state to Pennsylvania.  I worry everyday that the next news I'm going to hear is he is dead.  I pray for him every night.

name: Friend
text:
My best friend of 10+ years met a guy and he has gotten her addicted to heroin. She got clean for a little bit and left him but then something made her go back to him. She has started using again and does not talk to anyone, including family. Every day we fear she will wind up dead either from the heroin or from her abusive boyfriend. Her family and I stay in contact and constantly worry about her. She has become a totally different person. She is frail and looks so sick all of the time. 

Please,  if you or anyone you know is addicted to anything, please get help. It not only has an effect on you personally, but your loved ones as well.

name: Michael
text: At first it was a total friend... Calming storms that brewed in me for years... I lost my mother to this disease and a really special friend... I was in every stage of great at any moment due to a psychological disorder I had and I thought heroin was the answer... I didn't know or was to blind to see what destruction it would cause to my body, mind, and spirit... I tried countless times to stop with the same result being picking back up. December 2 2013 I thought I've had enough doing an extreme amount of dope I knew would end up killing me. I laid 10 hours on my basement floor! I died twice on the way to the hospital. They finally got me stable yet my lungs could not breath on their own and I was in a coma... Last second after being told to expect the worst from Doctors to my family God interveined and gave me a second chance... A medical miracle dr's say when I could have faced a life confined to a hospital bead or worse... I am one of the ones who were spared...

name: Brian
text: My best friend since freshman year of high school began using heroin two years after we graduated. When we were younger we where inseparable. As he began to use harder drugs we began to become more distant. As I began to peruse a Law Enforcement career, I had made the choice to not associate with him much anymore. After he was arrested a few time he began to wise up, and reached out to me. We began to patch our relationship up as he began to seem dedicated to living the sober life after some time in rehab and jail. There would be times were we would be out and he would have no money, then all of a sudden have money at the end of the day from stealing from peoples wallets they left around in the locker rooms of hockey rinks and pay me back for gas and food. Once I realized what he was doing, I had to distant myself again as I didn't want to put myself around the crimes he was committing. I lived everyday of my life waiting for the call or to read in the paper that he was dead from an overdose. We had friends from highschool overdosing and dieing and I had it embedded in my mind that he would be next. That feeling that I might never of seen my best friend alive again gave me nightmares and broke my heart.  He eventually overdosed and needed a "Narcan"shot to be bought back to life. After he reached out to me again, he finally realized how his actions were effecting his friends and family. Now we are pretty good friends again, not back to were we used to be, but close. I try to be a more positive influence on his life. I feel that if I can make time for him to go out and do sober things with myself, it will help keep him out of trouble, and it seems to be working as he just hit 1 year clean. He eventually became my inspiration and motivation to be a law enforcement officer because I would like to stop youth from making the same mistakes he made as a youth.
quote: He finally realized how his actions were effecting his friends and family

name: Vickie
text: My son died of a heroin overdose on April 5th, 2009. He was not an addict. He was 25 when he passed. The devastation it has made on our lives will never leave us. We are left with so many unanswered questions, frustrations, anger, hopelessness, grief, pain, and trying to cope with this giant void in our lives.

name: Paul
text: ive been through crazy battles with my ex/girl who is an addict. ive seen the bad shit that dope makes you do. she does good for a while and then thinks that she will be ok doing it once and picks it up again. im scarred for her life. and the odd thing is shes been to a few funerals this past year but still relapsed. seems like she has to look within to get better and sometimes that can be a scary thing

name: Andi
text: I am the mother of a former heroin addict.  She started at 19 and thank God got cleaned after two horrible, miserable years...hers and mine.  It is indescribable what this drug does to the user and family.  What helped ME was NarAnon, what helped my daughter was seven months away from home in rehab.  Two years of hell.  It's been two years since the nightmare ended but it left some very deep scares on me.  I pray every night for my friends at NarAnon and their loved ones who are SUFFERING with this addiction.  The stories I have heard at my meetings are absolutely unbelievable how this drug takes over.  Homelessness, abuse, death doesn't even stop them.

name: Jack
text: Heroin and prescription drugs are ruining the lives of many families, My son started with pot, to dealing then using. He went from pot to Oxy's then heroin. Currently he is in methadone program. My hope is to reach parents just getting exposed to this living nightmare. We have done everything to help him, several rehab's and restrictions have little results. They have to be ready. I'm no longer worried about bad guys robbing our home. Its our son who we have given all to who has taken the most from us. Thousands of dollars in legal fees and rehabs. Countless trips to court and probation and the saga continues. We were relieved when he was assigned to drug court in Monmouth Cty, I felt Judge Scully and Adri Lieb's team were tough, But actually cared for the drug users and their families. My son had his first meeting on Christmas eve in drug court a couple of years ago. We thought he would be processed into the program and get the ball rolling to recovery. To my shock he failed the initial drug test and was sent to county jail. It was a long ride home that Christmas eve. He was allowed to stay in the program, But was kicked out after failing again and sent to state prison. I agreed with Judge Scully's decision and support Drug Court 100%. When my son returned he was clean for awhile, Walking his talk, But things slipped back to his old ways of lies and deceit. My suggestion to parents facing this challenge is to not give them a cent. Bring tough love to a level you never thought possible. Parents and Loved ones suffer so much from worrying, You are no longer your kids priority, The next score is. Your addicted kid will bankrupt you if you allow them to. Protect yourself and your family. I strongly feel stricter enforcement should be put in place regarding prescription drugs. Its too easy for them to get. Why would government allow this to continue??? Even the most recent restrictions are not tough enough. Drug addiction is bigger than us. We need help, Our countries future depends on it.

name: Logan
text:
I spent about six months addicted to heroin. My older brothers friend sold it to me, talking about it like it was just like drinking a beer, wasn't as bad as everyone says. I successfully quit, calling the dealer in a bout of rage, yelling at him to never sell any to me again. Nobody knew about my problems, only me and the dealer. I'm a quiet type of person and my parents might just be a little gullible and think too much of me, my grades and behavior just as good as ever. I look back and remember only the withdrawals and pain, none of the temporary moments of bliss it had created. I remember the sleepless nights, the heavy weight of fatigue, the constant yawning and the watery eyes. I could go on and explain the more horrid withdrawal details, but I won't. It feels like a mixture of a horrible hangover and the flu; and you have to try to hide it from everyone, continue on with your school and work. I hated life when I didn't have it, and it makes me sad thinking about it. I sometimes think of myself as strong for successfully stopping on my own, but looking back, I think I should have gotten help. I wouldn't suggest anyone going through it alone. 

I guess why I consider my story unique is that I was the most unlikely person to become a drug addict. No one knew about it, because I was worried and aware enough to cover up the empty heroin packages; I mostly had it in my desk drawer, used it, and put it quickly back in the drawer, talking to my parents down stairs like the normal person they'd always known. I had mostly all 'A' grades in high school as well as taking college courses to get ahead. I wasn't a stereotypical user; I wasn't insanely skinny, didn't have tattoos or long hair. I just made a bad choice and continued making the same choice, always aware of the consequences and situation, but never willing to actually do anything about it. Eventually, I did. My whole life had turned into 'according to heroin', an annoying voice telling me what I could or couldn't do because I needed to leave time to get high. Not anymore. Not ever. 

I realize this is a bit long, if you would like to do a full article on me, I would do it; I consider myself a writer and have an even longer, more encompassing nonfiction piece about my heroin abuse, if wanted. If not, feel free to cut my word count down to a paragraph or so. I'll leave my email.

name: Angela
text: before heroin I experimented with drugs but was never an "addict" we just celebrated my daughter, the love.of my lifes, first birthday. Me and her father had a bad break up and my mother would watch her on the weekends for me while I went out. I was dating someone who was currently clean for about a year and he suggested doing it and I had plently of friends offer it to me before and I always said no I dont know what made me say yes that time but my life quickly spiraled out of control and everything that I loved and worked hard for fell to the waist side as I struggled to either maintain my addiction or get clean. Ive been to countless detoxes, rehabs, hospitals, jails, and states trying to stay clean but it never lasted. I also have tried 12 step programs and while I see that working in other peoples lives it hasnt for me...yet. I have two kids now andsome might say I love my addiction more than them they couldn't be more wrong. I wish they was a solution, I wish it was just as easy as not doing it but its not. Im clean today after being in another rehab back in march in which time I missed my daughters 11th birthday and my sons first day in head start and so far so good but its always in the back of my mind. What if I mess up again. I attend 12 step meetings and go to church but ive done all this before. quote: I wish there was a solution, I wish it was just as easy as not doing it, but it's not.

name: Rob
text: I used opiates and heroin for 9 years, it started with prescription pills like vicodan and percocet, then moved on to oxy. As pills became harder to find and more expensive, someone introduced me to heroin. From the first time I tried it I was hooked. I started out sniffing it but eventually turned to injecting. It didn't take long before it controlled every aspect of my life. I was begging for money at stores, stealing, selling things, borrowing money, and selling more heroin to anyone I could to make an extra buck to buy more. The final 3 to 3 1/2 years were the worst.  I was working side jobs to get money, would turn around and spend that on heroin, do as much of it as I could afford and sell the rest to be able to get more. I overdosed one night and ended up getting possession charges. Didn't go to court and kept on using and selling. After 7 month the law finally caught up with me. I went to jail with a 30+ bag a day habit. I spent 45 days in jail before being bailed out. I was on probation and entered into the ARD program which I successfully completed and now been clean for a year and 8 months and hold down a full time job. I consider myself one of the lucky ones that was able to make it through and turn my life around.  (This was very shortened version of a long long journey)

name: Rick
text: I am currently living with my parents going in and out of the bathroom to tie off my arm. I live in the suburbs and go into Trenton to buy everyday. I constantly worry of arrest, being robbed, or getting a batch that will lead to my death. None of it matters to me though due to my need to get high. It is no longer a need to get high, but rather the need to get well. Once withdraw begins to set in, you will do anything to have it end. I started using percocet, which escalated to heroin, which escalated to shooting heroin, all within the course of a year. Addiction is a disease, one that feels impossible to shake, and suicide becomes an all too real possibility. Not to long ago I was a college student, had all the friends one could ask for, a loving girlfriend and a family that loved and trusted me. Today I am a heroin addict with none of those things. Opiates don't just ruin your health and wallet, they take your soul, and everything around you.
quote: I am currently living with my parents going in and out of the bathroom to tie off my arm.

name: Betsy
text: My son has been battling addiction for seven years now and it has totally destroyed us and him both emotionally, financially and health wise. H was not able to complete his college degree due to his addiction, lost all of his friends and isn't able hold a job.  There have been times where even his family had to turn their backs on him for his destructive ways. He has made poor choices in relationships and it wasn't until recently that he has had substantial clean time.......He may have finally turned the corner.
quote: He may have finally turned the corner.

name: D
text:
My 19 year old daughter is an addict.  Former honor roll student/cheerleader.  We have always been closer than normal mother/daughter's that I know.  Started using heroin right before her 17th birthday, with her boyfriend at the time.  She hid it from me, until I called her out on it after Christmas of her senior year in high school.  It has been a nightmare since then to say the least.  Outpatient, 4 detoxes, 6 thirty day inpatient programs, 2 attempts at sober living homes...she is currently living with a "friend" or so I am told2 hours away. I know she is using again.  Too many details to write about....bottom line is she needs long term treatmentwhich is something my insurance does not cover...they will only cover 28 days.  She does not want this lifeshe has written some amazing pieces while in treatment, which are honest and heartfelt.  She is a caring, respectful, young girl, but she is addicted.  
I am terrified that this will take her life.

name: Ann
text:
I have a sibling who is an addict.  Says he's off, but if he is not lying, we all know in the end he will go back to it.  He doesn't have a job  just works occasionally.  seems to find ways to get $$ for his habits, but always broke.  recently got medicaid, thanks to Christie's expansion under Obamacare.  A financial drain on our whole family.  He lives w my 75 yr old parents, who don't have the means to deal with this!  He has stolen from them, lied, cheated, etc. all of us.   
The big issue I see is that our medical system is set up so that friends & family can't get help on behalf of another adult.  It's against the law for the Dr.'s office to tell me whether he is actually going for his treatment.  He's depressed, and so deranged from so many years on drugs, that he can't see that he needs help (not just Methadone help!).  Yet those around him have no power or right to get help for him.  Very frustrating!!

name: Shannon
text:
My 22 year old daughter has been using since 2011, I first found out on 7811 when a fellow coworker called telling me "shannon we are taking Ashley to the hospital CPR in progress. She overdosed on heroin" 
I have had her in  8 rehabs across PA, NJ, NY, FL.. I have tried dedicated committed supportive tactics, to "tough love" distant struggle tactics. 
It makes it so difficult for our family because we still go to work everyday an deal with perfect strangers suffering or dieing from addiction. I have to stuff my own feeling aside and deal with their pain. 
Everything in my education tells me there is nothing I can do to save her other than love her.

name: Anthony
text: I have a son 53 yrs. old, became addicted to prescribed drug medication and then to heroin, had a back injury years ago which led to substance abuse, his companion of 16 yrs passed away earlier this year and he lost everything he owned, we took him in to try to help him, it became a nightmare, the only help a person can get without insurance coverage is hospital emergency, in and out prescribe more drug use in and out, he has finally realized he needed help and is now in the third week in a Salvation Army facility we are praying this will help him,

name: Jane
text: I lost my 23 year old son to a heroin overdose.  He started using pain meds after his wisdome teeth were removed.  Pills became too expensive and in a sober house someone suggested he try heroin.  The downward spiral began for multiple hospitalizations, arrests etc.  He overdosed in September of 2011.  We tried putting him in a facility, outpatient rehab, and finally just making it almost impossible for him to leave home.  He overdosed after attending  (that was his excuse) a AA meeting.

name: Meryl
text: My 25 year old son, Ben, was a heroin addict for quite a few years. He was in and out of several rehabs, over the years, stealing from us, lying, and doing awful things. Once he would start to show progress, the insurance company would claim he did not need inpatient treatment (after only 30 days) and should go to outpatient treatment; however, within only a few days, he would relapse and the entire nightmare would begin again. He spent over two years in county jail. Finally (thankfully), he was accepted into Drug Court. He has now been over a year clean. Only 2 days before leaving many months of inpatient treatment, our older son, Sam (who was 28) tragically died from a blood clot in his coronary artery. Sam and Ben had been very close and both were looking forward to a renewed relationship, once Ben left inpatient treatment. Sadly, this was not to be. Ben was released the day before Sam's memorial service. (April 2014) Ben stood up before all of our friends and family members and stated that losing his brother could be seen as a reason to relapse. However, he stated that although he was feeling great pain and loss, he would continue with his battle to stay clean. It is now a little over a year that he has remained clean. He's working, has made changes in his life and is doing well. Ben lives with his father in Summit; I am in Toms River. He has come a very long way. I am grateful to the staff at Drug Court (Union County) for helping Ben with his recovery.

name: Linda
text: My son has been a heroin addict for over half his life.It has torn my family apart.We have tried numerous rehabs paid and no pay but he always has an excuse for leaving.He is currently in jail for VOP. For the first time I am cutting myself off from him hoping he gets drug court and the help he needs. It is killing me but maybe he will get the help he needs.

name: Chris
text: When i was age 22 i was a full blown heroin addict,like many of my friends. I was pretty much disowned by my whole family and on my own. I maintained a job as long as i could.When my addiction progressed i could no longer work and my only goal everyday was finding a way to get money to purchase heroin to keep from getting physicslly ill. With out getting into to much detail, stealing from family, robbing people,stores or cash registers when no one was looking. This became my daily life and deep inside it sickened me at what i had become. After a few months in county jail and time to think i got myself into a long term inpatient treament facility in Newark NJ.Now coming from where i grew up i was in complete culture shock. Welfare payed for my housing and the food we ate there. I learned how to be a human being again,work ethic and be a moral individual. I completed my rehabilitation moved back to my parents at age 24 and spent everyday attending NA meetings,working and living life sober. Once i got into a routine and kept my self occupied and away from people that used life was so much better then i could have ever imagined.I met my wife within those first two years and got married and had a child by my third year clean.I finally grew up and became the man my parents could be proud of. After alot of hard work i purchased my first home at age 27 and still live there until this day and have been married 11 years now,with three children. I appreciate everything i have now although i sometimes forget and take things for granted but,so does everyone. As long as i use the tools i learned in the first two years clean i feel i can accomplish anything i set my mind to. I've lost alot of people along the way to this disease of addiction and some i know are still struggling there is hope for anyone as long as they want it bad enough for THEMSELVES. doing it for anyone but yourself is the road to failure right from the start.

name: April
text: My son( 34 years old) first became addicted to pain pills then onto heroin. He lost everything.His job that he had for14 years, his family,his car, his phone but most importantly his self.He is in treatment now at Americas Keswick.And is doing great it is a great program and I see the changes in him.He as been in treatment many times in the secular treatment centers. They could not help him.

name: Natalie
text: I am a 32 year old woman who was born and raised in Newark.  It wasn't until I moved out to Warren County for a brief period of time (about 6 months) that I had my first experience with Heroin.  Not personally, but it was personal.  Sometime around April of last year, I found my boyfriend in the bathroom... somewhere between half dead and alive.  He was overdosing on Heroin.  How did I know it was heroin?  There was a syringe floating in the bathroom sink, and little envelopes strewn across the floor.  This was how I was first introduced to my boyfriend's battle with addiction.  It was every bit as dirty and scary as it is portrayed in the movies.   It was at that very moment that my life as I knew it, would never be the same. Right now, my boyfriend sits in a jail for having relapsed and failing a drug test administered by Parole.  People talk about reaching bottoms, but how do you know where bottom is when you can't live without the one thing that is killing you.  My boyfriend has been in jail for the past few months and when he is released from jail, he will go directly to Rehab.  That is, if there is an open bed, of course.  As for myself, I take every day, one day at a time, and never for granted.  It is difficult not having my partner by my side, but I say to myself, at least he is still alive.

name: Drea
text: I used heroin for 19 years, I been to prison, I been in the county jail to many times. For 5 years now I've been on methadone which has saved my life. I know many will say that I am still using, but it is give to me by a doc. I am able to work, be a mother and pay my bills now. I am now a productive citizens and I know this will be a battle for the rest of my life, but with my families support I can beat this and maybe one day be clean from even the methadone.
