name: G
text: using heroin was an easy way out, it wasn't an excuse and it's still not. I started using back on 2008 and it was my way of hiding my feeling or the things I was going though not having someone to trust or talk to people and family members are quick to judge. no one asks what's the reason you chose to use. everyone has there own way of dealing with stress, depression and sadness. using heroin was my way out of reality until I was so far into it. I new I had a problem and I wanted out not only for me but for my 2 beautiful kids they didn't deserve it. I got my self help twice and went to the same place both time when I spoke to the councilor and she told me if you come back a third time we are going to take your kids and at that point I new that I didn't want to put my kids though that, that was my wake up call and I've been clean for 6 years. I've gotten help to deal with my depression and stress. no one will ever know how hard it is to get off the drug and the reason why most people use. some people are stronger than other and everyone deals with there own situation differently when your an addict its very hard to ask for help.

name: Charles
text: I am a recovering heroin addict that started at a young age of 17. I joined the military and the stress and depression that it caused started me using it while in service which destroyed my career. after discharge in 2009 I have been running unable to stop, treatment centers not doing any good, and progressively collecting charge after charge from its grasp. it was never enough I could never find enough will power to stop even after me and my friends realized this is not fun anymore this way of life is horrific. waking up everyday sick wanting a way to kill yourself til u get a temporary fix was never a way to live I expected to stoop down to. finally after spending most of the last year in jail I decided I have had enough ive been homeless on the streets since 2009 only surviving, and barely that. all my so called friends are dying and I felt everyday like I hoped this last shot would do that same effect for me. to end the misery. people stuck in addiction have no out. even if offered it still haunts you in dreams and thoughts through the day. I just decided I need to change my life I cant do this anymore, my family, teachers, real friends, expected more from me along with myself being an A student in H.S. its a struggle I wont wish on my worst enemies foreign or domestic. NA and AA meetings I go to every day, and its just a lifestyle some with the power to not say no may never escape. jail doesn't help because once your released you looking to get high. something must change for this unfortunates
quote: I just decided I need to change my life I cant do this anymore

name: Suzette
text: My son was addicted to opiates for years. At his lowest, he was inviting himself and hoping from ER to ER for prescription medications. He ended up in jail and found treatment nearly impossible to secure. It will be his lifelong struggle.

name: Annmarie
text: My life changed a year ago when to my complete shock I learned that my bright, college going 23 year old was addicted to heroin. Our life has been a rollercoaster of legal cases and battles with insurance to find the right treatment programs. My son has been to the brink of death and now fights every day to stay clean but I had to send him far away to get the kind of treatment that should have been avialble here in NJ. I was so unaware of the availablity of this drug and its impact on so many across our town, county and state. This drug has impacted every aspect of our lives and our childrens lives, but we have a strong resolve to battle this alongside my son.

name: Brenda
text: My son was 19 when he was addicted to heroine and from dirty needles and a infected tooth he had endocarditis which led to a stroke and open heart surgery. He is now partially paralyzed on his left side and has an artificial heart valve. My 28 year old son was addicted to prescription pain killers and has been in and out of jail for about 10 years now. I told the cops back when my first son was addicted that we had an epidemic and they needed to do something than.
quote: He is now partially paralyzed on his left side and has an artificial heart valve.

name: James
text: Our son took oxycontin for a minor back injury and after the subscription was up he started buying opiates on the black market first prescription drugs and then a new girlfriend who was a heroin addict introduced him to heroin. He now is in rehab for the 7th time in 17 months. He has lost jobs, now committed crimes and has done other nasty things to get the heroin.  This revolving door where the insurance companies he has good insurance will only pay for 30 days of rehab is NOT working!  All the rehab places he has been to have said short term treatment does not work. All Governments in the US have to join the California Counties and the City of Chicago's suit against the drug makers that have helped create this epidemic by making them pay for long term treatment of the drug addicts.  Minimums should be 12 months of treatment.  Additionally, instead of jail there are innovative programs that allow the drug user to go work at a facility and they donate their time for treatment, food and lodging and work to let them beat the addiction and then move back into society  at very low cost. Laws need to allow sentencing to these innovative programs if not voluntary. Spending $100K a year to put drug users in jail is useless costly and does not work they get no treatment in jail.  Our family is in crisis our marriage is in shambles and may end over this and our finances are being destroyed with all the costs to get treatment for our son. We are a middle class suburban family that has never had any trouble with the law or drugs and our son is the first to ever use heroin or opiates in our whole family.  Government needs to lead the charge to sue the Oxycontin pushing drug companies to make them pay the billions that this is costing the nation, the crimes that these drug addicts are committing to get their drugs and to stop the many lives being lost to the addiction their drugs have caused.

name: David
text:
It has affected everyone in my family.  I am married, I have two children, a loving wife, a loving mother, seven supportive brothers and sisters.  I became addicted to pain medication, specifically Oxycotin.  I started out using percocet, then worked my way up to Oxycotin.  Owning a pizzeria, I stole from my business, my partner and friend, to support my expensive habit.  I was taking so many pain pills a day, I am so lucky that I did not die.  Near the end, I was snorting heroin if I was not able to get hold of pain pills.  My life revolved around how I was going to get them, how I was going to pay for them, and when I was going to use them.  I would go through withdrawals and have to wake up at 5am to take a pill, just to be able to sleep.  Thankfully (I can say that now), my supplier, my employee, got arrested.  The police had done an investigation on him, and during that investigation I was on tape buy from him. The police did not want to prosecute the buyers, but instead, called my partner and me in to headquarters and basically had an intervention.  I was exposed but relieved.  My partner, now knowing that I had caused our business woos, wanted nothing to do with me.  

Great news,  I am now clean and sober 2 1/2 years!  I am no longer a partner in that pizzeria.  I went to rehab for 40 days.  My insurance would pay for detox, but after detox, would only pay for out patient rehab.  My wife knowing now how bad I was, knew that I could not come home right away.  She cried to the insurance company, but to no avail.  St Clares hospital found a rehab in Florida that would take the same amount that the insurance company would pay for out patient.  It was the best thing for me. 

I still have my wife, my kids, my family and a few friends.  I lost my partner, my friend.  That hurts the most.  I go to my meetings 4 times a week, and have NOT relapsed.  I am in a much better place now.  I have just bought my own pizzeria/restaurant.  I should be opening in mid October.

name: Jen
text: My brother 36 and sister in law 33 have struggled with heroin addiction for the last few years. With no health insurance they could only get a few days in detox which is not nearly enough to start recovery. They have lost their kids, jobs, home and now my brother is incarcerated for theft and she is missing. Their kids and family has been ripped apart! They are the nicest caring parents/people when sober. I hope and pray that we can somehow help addics overcome this horrible addiction! So many people are struggling with it or someone with it! So sad!
quote: They have lost their kids, jobs, home and now my brother is incarcerated for theft and she is missing.

name: Liz
text: Both my sons age 19 and 22 are addicts. We have been on this emotional roller coaster  for the past seven years. My older son is a heroin addict and younger one is addicted to pills (opiates and benzos) . They are both chronic relapsers and have been in just about every facility in NJ and several in Florida.  The laws and treatment seriously need to be changed. The chronic nature of addiction is extremely difficult to overcome.This disease has broken my family emotionally and financially. I would like to be an advocate to help resolve some of the roadblocks to getting addicts the appropriate help.

name: Ariel
text: It has destroyed my life..I've been battling this hell since I was 15.I still struggle to this day..I get clean then I relapse. I've lost jobs,relationships with friends,girlfriends and family.I feel hopeless.no reason to live.I hate my life because of this.we need serious help.
quote: I feel hopeless. No reason to live.I hate my life because of this. We need serious help.

name: Barbara
text: Heroin abuse has directly devastated our family. The addiction is a life long battle for the addict and their family.  Not enough is being done to stop the drugs coming into the US and not enough treatment is being authorized by the insurance companies for those that have insurance and for those without insurance, treatment is  extremely limited.  mental Health and substance abuse needs to be treated as every other illness.  Nj I should have a law like New York called "Timothy's Law for mental health and create a law similar for substance abuse.

name: Rena
text: My children's father is a heroin addict...currently incarcerated for past heroine related crimes.....I have never seen the dark side like I have with this addiction. ..it is unlike anything I ever could imagine. ..and I have a bit of experience,  my father was a drug addict too.....to look at me and my home and see how I live, you would never think I'm in the situation I'm in.....I could tell people things that would make their heads spin but I'm scared of what they may think.....my fiance is a regular working family guy who has been rocked to the core by this drug....He almost died (had to be revived with paddles) twice and by the grace of God he is as alive and breathing ..I know the man I love it just sick, this drug is SICK and what it does to people and their families is incomprehensible......I am angry, drained, sad, scared, heartbroken,  stunned, robbed, manipulated, ect......These feelings are enough to rob someone of their soul........I would love to help in any way I can if it could benefit others

name: Linda
text: My son became addicted to heroin when drugs were given to him when he was a teenager. Soon after, he lost control of making the right decisions and got into trouble . First, traffic violations, then other trouble. He was so sick from heroin use, I thought he was dying.  This disease has caused extreme heartbreak and stress to our Family. He was incarcerated and we hired Attorneys for his defense. He grew up with good morals and a strong Faith in God. He is Intelligent and had plans for College. He even attended College for a brief time. He lost many years of his life from this horrible addiction. When he was younger, he wanted to be a DR. or a Police Officer. He is clean Today, and I am grateful. Something needs to be done NOW to get drugs off our streets. I pray for the Families who lost or live with or Love an addict. I got through the most difficult times,( when he was homeless) by going to the online support groups, for Families of addicts.

name: Brandon
text: Heroin destroyed me and everything and anyone I came into contact with. I started using heroin when I was 17 years old. I was trying every drug out there and heroin was on my list. I really liked being high. I didn't like myself, and getting high made me a different person...so I thought. And in reality it did. It turned me into a monster. I never thought in a million years id be a junkie. I grew up as a suburban white boy who was handed everything growing up. I had everything I ever wanted...besides the love for myself. Once I tried that dope, it had me. It was over, heroin is the love of my life. And it was for the next 4 years. I dropped out of high school, was in and out of countless amounts of rehabs and detoxes. I moved out of New Jersey thinking New Jersey was my problem. But my problems followed. I moved out to arizona in dec 2012, and in less then a month I had a needle in my arm. I couldn't stop. I didn't want to die, I just needed heroin to live. I couldn't live without heroin in my veins. It's really sad. It destroyed everything I once had. I had no one. Nothing. Homeless. Junkie. Nothing. Junkie. Nothing. No one. Alone. I was completely alone. I then went to my 12th rehab because I couldn't live like that anymore. I couldn't. Since then, I've been clean 7 months next week. And it's something I work at everyday. I work my 12 steps on a daily basis. Im spiritual. Im a changed person. It's so weird. I'd elaborate more but I'm currently in a meeting and on my phone. I'm still sick, alright. Drugs and alcohol aren't my problem, im my problem.

name: Linda
text: My son has been battling drug addiction since he was 14 years old. He is now 43 years old and is incarcerated.  That's where his addiction led him. He is not, nor has he ever been, violent.  His addiction was the reason for stealing and occasionally selling drugs.  Anything to support his habit.  He was diagnosed with bipolar disorder in his twenties.  By that time, he had already been selfmedicating.  He never used drugs to "party" he used drugs to "try to feel normal."  He has been in and out of treatment facilities his entire life.  Successfully completing the programs then released, only to end up back on drugs because he couldn't afford mental health treatment or the drugs he needed to combat the bipolar disorder. It's been a vicious cycle for him.  Clean and sober, my son is the kindest, most gentle man one could know.  He's a joy to be around and extremely caring.  My son on drugs will lie, cheat, steal, manipulate and do whatever else he must in order to support his habit.  This time, it all caught up with him.  He cannot believe he's incarcerated.  He never believed it would happen.  Talk about scared straight; I'm hoping this does it for him.  He recently told me that, "God is doing for me, what I couldn't do for myself."  He understands that he is where he is because he never addressed his underlying issues. His mental health issues.  He is seeing a psychiatrist in jail, and is receiving medication that seems to be really helping him.  I pray that when he's released, he will be able to secure some assistance so that he may continue with his counseling AND his medication.  I am retired and cannot afford to help him.  A hell of a position for a mother to be in, regardless of her child's age.  Anything that can be done to help people like my son secure treatment and medication, will not only benefit the addict but everyone s/he comes in contact with.  In the end, it will also save the taxpayers the incredible amounts of money it costs to incarcerate drug users.

name: Dave
text: I have been addicted for 13 years and have no idea how to quir... I want to but i just can't seem to do it... I feel like I'm losing a uphill and impossible battle!!!

name: Tara
text: Having survived an addiction to opioids 11 years ago and currently working in the substance abuse treatment field for 9 years, I have witnessed the epidemic first hand. I have seen the face of the opioid addict change; it's gotten younger, it's gotten older, it's kept cloaked and it's scarily more available. I have seen many people die despite their best efforts at recovery. It's not only traumatizing to those of us who see it first hand but as a society that's becoming numb and dismissive to a vulnerable disenfranchised group of suffering individuals. I pray for people to have compassion and understanding for those of us who are not battling this deadly daemon

name: Stephen
text: I am a person in long term recovery. I started off with drugs by smoking weed and drinking in high school.  I had problems all throughout school. When I was 20 I got my first prescription of percocet for my first of many aaccidents.then I started buying the pills off the street once the scripts ran out. Then once the pills became to expensive I was introduced to a 10 dollar bag that in the pill form would be a 100 dollar. This story is not unique I cannot emphasis this enough you will hear it over and over again. Eventually I ended up sticking needle in my arm. Today I will have 2 years clean. This is after 2 felonies and going thru probation successfully.
quote: This story is not unique  I cannot emphasis this enough  you will hear it over and over again

name: Matt
text: Hey I am Matt and I'm a recovering addict. Heroin has affected me so much these past couple years. I was in and out of treatment for years. Coming from a decent home, my disease though other wise, I did what ever was possible to just get one more. Robbing, stealing, dealing, lying, etc. I have overdosed 11 times in 3 years. Not only was I a heroin user but a crack cocaine user. I ran the streets of Camden just to get high. I lost so many loved ones to this disease and today I will not stand to loose myself. I was arrested in Atlantic City with heroin a couple years ago, and that did not stop me to getting just one more. Today I have 6 months off all mind altering substances. If you're in recovery, keep coming back!

name: Michele
text: I live every taking pills to get by not to get high but by... it's a battle I'm losing and help is expensive .. I work but still can't afford the help . I have lost all motivation and just want the old me back =(
quote: I have lost all motivation and just want the old me back

name: Terri
text: My son nearly died last July from a heroin overdose. This demon has torn our families lives apart!  After drug court sent him to a facility in Secaucus twice, he has now been clean for 15 months!  We are finally living as a family again and he is doing so well. I thank GOD everyday for giving him another chance. I would love to become a counselor so that I could help other parents struggling with this aweful disease.  It has and continues to take too many lives. It is horrific and so destructfull.

name: Corey
text:
Our 22 year old daughter is an opiate addict for over two years. Started with Roxycodone inhaled and now heroin /cocaine injected. Has had 5 medical detoxes and completed one full rehab program in Florida (inpatient 7 weeks, IOP and sober house for 3 months) in Florida. Has relapsed so many times. She is currently on the Vivitrol program of monthly injections to keep her off heroin. She is two weeks clean. Facing some felonies and drug court. Has no money, car, phone and bounces around. So very sad. She has stolen money and jewelry from every family member. 
I can tell you how this addiction has affected her loving parents and brother: we are numb. We love our daughter but HATE heroin. Lost her natural grace, humor, creativity and intelligence of her soul. Heroin is now the driver of her body. She has become a thief, liar and fearless risk taker, that takes no responsibility for her actions. My beautiful daughter has a brain that is fueled by the cravings of opiate addiction. We have been told countless times to "release with love", so she can hit rock bottom.It is so very hard to turn your back on someone you love. Someone who is damaged from drug use.

name: Alicia
text:
Dear Jess,

It's been eight years since you succumbed to your demons. I remember that day so vividly.

��_��_��_Jess is gone,��_� my dad told me.

��_��_��_Gone? She ran away?��_�

��_��_��_No. She��_�s GONE.��_�

I��_�ve written about you twice. Twice in eight years. Short pieces, never going into much detail.  Most people I have met in my adult life know I have a cousin who passed away when we were just 19yearsold, but they hardly ask ��_��_��_how?��_� and I never tell them.

The truth of the matter is: how do you explain to someone that a beautiful, educated, funny, wellread, athletic girl with a 10pm curfew was found unresponsive in an apartment with a needle in her arm?  People have a way of pigeonholing those who suffer from addiction as ��_��_��_trash��_� or ��_��_��_junkies��_� or ��_��_��_criminals��_� and that��_�s hardly ever the case.  Addiction is an illness. They had families. They had aspirations. Christ, when you started using you were in honors classes at a competitive high school. One decision, one lapse in judgment, can alter the course of an entire life. I know that��_�s what happened to you, and I have refused to let 18 months out of an entire 19 years on this earth dictate your memory. So why am I writing this now?

Just the other day, your mother said to me: ��_��_��_I thought things were supposed to get easier after eight years.��_�  A lot has happened, Jess.  But you still have a mom and a dad, and they still have a daughter. Your dad has made it his mission to tell your story at high schools, hoping to steer at least one student in another, less fatal, direction. And it seems, more so than when you were alive, Heroin has been pushed to the forefront of the news.  New Jersey is grappling with a spiraling heroin epidemic. Maybe, just maybe, your story will save someone from falling down the same harrowing rabbit hole you did. If not for themselves, for their families. You see, you didn��_�t survive your addiction, but we did ��_��_��_ barely.

I am mad, Jess. I miss you, but sometimes in between the sadness, I am mad. I am mad that I lost you long before you died. I am mad at you for what you put your parents through. I am mad that the last time we hung out together, I never changed out of my bathrobe because I was stubborn.   I am mad that your last words to me were, ��_��_��_See ya later, Cuz.��_� I am mad you never met your beautiful nieces.  I see a lot of you in them. I am mad they play ��_��_��_dress up��_� in your clothes, but have no idea how awesome you were as a person. I am mad you never met the man I am spending my life with.  I am mad that we celebrated your 21st birthday without you.  I am mad that my relationship with my aunt and uncle, your parents, has been strained ever since. None of us talk about it, but I feel it. I am a constant, gnawing reminder of what couldhavebeen for you. Some days I know it hurts, literally hurts, your mother to be around me. And I don��_�t blame her. I am mad the people you used with are still here and you��_�re not.  I am mad that instead of calling your parents that fateful day, you called a stranger you had met in rehab.

Drugs and the inevitable death that will follow kill more than just that person. Pieces of the people they leave behind are buried with them. After seven Christmases without you, your parents finally started putting up a Christmas tree again. Your bedroom is now a homeoffice.  Things I thought I would always recall about you are starting to fade. Jess, don��_�t you see? So much has happened, since everything happened. So much has changed, since everything changed. We were born 11 months apart, but I am nearly 10 years older than you now.  I am experiencing a chapter of my life that I never got to share with you and that kills me.  We didn��_�t have enough time together. You didn��_�t have enough time to get it together.

No, you didn��_�t survive your addiction, but I know because of you others survived their own addictions. My sister, unfortunately, experienced her own battle with drugs, but your loss motivates her to stay clean.  She is thriving now, and she told me she thanks you. She says you may very well be the sole reason she never experimented with Opiates. If that��_�s true, I have to thank you as well, because I need my sister on this planet.

So, is this literally everything I have wanted to say to you the last eight years? Probably not. But Jess, I will go on living my life never having the one question I need answered, answered. It was the last thing I asked you when we were sitting on my living room couch that day. ��_��_��_Why do you do this, Jess?��_�

WHY? That is definitely the most asked, and yet least answered question of all time. The question after all of these life choices is always: but why? Unfortunately, there may never be an answer to this question, at least there wasn��_�t in your lifetime. So it remains unexplained, no reason given, just that we are human and nothing more. And that, Jess, is very unfortunate.

I miss you,

I love you,

and I will see ya later, Cuz.

Love,

Alicia

name: Kathy
text: My son and ~many~ of his friends are heroin addicts. He has lost a few friends to overdose, and has od'd himself, more than once. He has been arrested several times, he has court dates coming here in town, at county court in Belvidere and Essex County within the next month or so. This has cost him custody of his 3 year old daughter, though we are hoping that is just temporary. I have turned to support groups online for support and education o this subject. I especially like The Addict's Mom and TAM NJ Chapter on Facebook.

name: Nell
text: Being with someone addicted to heroin has affected me and children in many ways. You don't trust leaving anything of value around for fear that it will go missing. Emotionally it has been draining. It's very hard to see the negative changes going on and trying to get help is few and far in between especially with no medical insurance. The quick get yourself clean detox centers do nothing but give you a false sense of hope. They go back out and use and you're back on this roller coaster. I finally had to give up after 7 years of trying to be understanding and patient. Now my family is broken and what can I say to my children that keep asking for their father? It's heartbreaking.

name: Ashley
text: I am a recovering heroin addict. I have ben clean since August 15, 2013. I have been in an out of treatment many of times,this time God willing, I am going to stay clean. I have lost many friends to this disease. I have overdosed a number of times. I always felt that society looked at us addicts as "junkies". We are people too and many of us came from great families. I am so happy to hear that politicians are finally acknowledging the epidemic.

name: Nancy
text: I have lived the nightmare as a parent of an addict.  He has received treatment a few times from the state because he does not work and has no insurance.  The problem is, they will only keep him for two weeks.  That is not long enough for rehab.  Why don't they just cut back on how many opportunities you can get but allow the addict the full time needed to deal with their addiction.  My life is a living hell because of heroin.  I come home every day expecting to see my son dead.  It has become rampant in our town.  We who do not have the money for the support services needed need help.
quote: I come home every day expecting to see my son dead.

name: Dominick
text: I have been battling addiction since I was 15 years old. It started with pot and pills and by the time I was 17, I had snorted my first bag of heroin. It was something I vowed I'd never do. Within 6 months of snorting the drug I began to inject it. My life spiraled and thankfully I have a family who picked up on it and couldn't handle watching me die any longer. They offered treatment and I went. I moved to California afterwards and worked my program to stay sober. It wasn't until after a year sober that I had relapsed and came back to NJ. Now at 19 I'm in early recovery yet again and am living in an oxford house in south jersey. I see how bad it is in our state. What led me into using heroin was how cheap and strong the high was compared to paying for pills. Id said I'd never try this drug, I said I'd never use a needle, or steal from my family. Everything changes when you start using dope. All my morals I was raised on went out the window. I'd like to see more done in NJ to support treatment and change the stigma. While I was in rehab in NJ at least 95% of people where there for heroin or opiates. It's scary. Today I'm continuing with aftercare in outpatient groups and daily AA meetings while living in an oxford house. I'm slowly feeling better mentally but there's always more I need to work on in recovery.

name: Tanya
text: Opiates have started affecting me about 4 years ago and continue to do so to this day. Unlike most opiate addicts, I actually started taking Suboxone (Buprenorphine and Naloxone) before I tried any other opiates. I knew someone who took it for opiate dependence and used it every now and then to subside my depression/anxiety, which was through the roof at the time. Several months later, I woke up one night in severe pain. My right side was absolutely killing me, and I ended up going to the hospital, to find out that I had a kidney stone. The doctor gave me Percocets. At first I used them as prescribed, but when I realized that taking one at a time wasnt quite making the pain go away completely, I decided to take 2. Twenty minutes later, I puked my guts out because I had no tolerance for them at the time. I remember thinking what a terrible idea that was...until I stopped puking, and realized that I was in a state of euphoria and completely painfree. Needless to say, the rest of those Percocets went rather quickly. When I ran out, I had a cooling off period. Several months later, someone I knew found out they had Stage 4 cervical cancer and probably only a few months left to live. She was getting prescribed Dilaudid and Fentanyl patches. When she did pass, she had a lot of medication left over. When I got to it, it was all gone within a week. Not too long after, someone I knew told me I should try heroin because it was, supposedly, a lot better, and more potent. I was afraid of overdosing because I didnt know how potent exactly it was, so I snorted half a bag at first. I fell in love, and snorted the other half an hour later. I kept snorting it for the next six months, and then decided to try shooting it. In between binges, I started taking Suboxone again on a regular basis because I was afraid of withdrawal. So, several years of that, and a lot of lying, cheating, stealing, and pawning, has gotten me to where I am today. My last relapse was about 3 months ago, Im still stuck on Suboxone and feeling hopeless about ever stopping even though I want to. The littlest things sometimes trigger me to want to get high. I try to avoid going certain places, seeing or hearing certain things...I have to build my entire life around what could possibly trigger me if I want to stay clean. Its the hardest thing ive ever had to go through. Ive hurt so many people including myself, took so many risks along the way, and didnt care about any consequences even though I knew they would happen. I could write a book about it all truthfully...its 4 years of pain, but it feels like a lifetime.

name: Eric
text:
From high hopes and a natural love for life to the last, daunting breaths of a despairing life. This could sum up my love affair with drugs and alcohol in a heartbeat. Drugs and alcohol did for me what I could never do for myself. I found a way to feel whole again, but neglected to see where the void came from.

Coming from a loving, but very angst filled family I knew something was off when I was 9 or 10 years old. Something just did not feel right within me; I knew I was doomed long before consuming drink or a drug. I worked hard in school and athletics and usually excelled with little effort. I loved my family, friends, and school with all of my heart. I was introduced to drugs and alcohol early on in high school, but you would have never suspected it to be a problem. I was a joy to be around, a hard worker, and loyal to a fault. Throughout college the using progressed, and with that ran the parallel internal feelings of struggle and despair. I'd say by 19 or 20 I was completely addicted, both physically and mentally, to drugs and alcohol. I graduated college with an excellent degree, but was shortly after in a hold that I could see no return from. I was stealing from everyone and being kicked out of all of my friends' and families' lives.

Before I knew it I was 23 and homeless. I had nowhere to go, and no one to call. I had realized I crossed the line from which there is no return. I plunged into the darkness praying for no return. I did not know any other options.

On January 29, 2011 I was saved strictly through the Grace of God. I had been physically separated from drugs and alcohol and introduced to 12 Step Recovery programs. I saw a glimpse of hope and knew this was my only chance. A gentleman extended his hand out to me and I grabbed it with a strong desparation. I have consistently sought to grow spiritually and enhance the lives of those that still suffer from addiction, and anyone else for that matter. My life today is filled with love, joy, beauty, and most importantly freedom. I am no longer a prisoner to drugs, alcohol, or myself. In the end I only had myself to blame, and today I only have God and others whose lives He has touched as well.

name: Dana
text:
I've been on heroin on and off since 2011. I knew I was addicted from the day I started. I didn't graduate to heroin like most people who were on pills first; I hung out with a coworker who did heroin one day .. she offered me some, and I was in love ever since.I went to detox once, inpatient rehab in FL twice, then stayed down in FL in halfway for 9 months. I hated FL; I never want to go back, not even for vacation lol. The longest I stayed clean off of heroin and all drugs was 10 months, 25 days .. I fucked that up because I relapsed up marijuana (my other DOC), and that relapsed progressed .. pot, crack, speed, then heroin. My last run was my shortest, about 4 months, but it was the shittiest .. they always say "you pick up right where you left off" and they're right. Although I still smoke pot occasionally, I don't mess with anything else .. well, I'll have a drink or two here in there. But the most important thing is that I've been off heroin for 2 months exactly today, thanks to methadone, which I've been on for a little over 2 months. The reason why so many people keep relapsing, IMO, is because they're completely abstinent, methadone (and suboxone, your choice .. I get mine state funded, so I can only get the meth). More people should taper down slowly.** Also, there's more than just NA/AA. IMO, the 12 step programs won't work for me, but that's also because I have borderline personality disorder and I NEED to tend to it first .. since I've been off heroin, it's big, ugly head is starting to show itself again, and I'm not beat for letting it try to destroy my life again (lost my son and his father due to it). I go to meetings sometimes, but it's myself that keeps my clean, not a meeting or god. MAYBE one day I'll take meetings seriously, get a sponsor, work steps, all that good stuff, but I need to get my BPD wayy under control first. OH! And people should be contacting the DMHAS  just google "dmhas nj" and search their website .. call the hotlines, email them .. THEY WILL HELP YOU.

**What I'm doing basically is trying to get my life completely stable before I even try to get off it .. if I got off any time before that, I'd be back in the same place I started, and I don't want that. I'm a 26 year old girl who should have a career, graduated college, have a car, a serious boyfriend, all that happy stuff that I want SO bad .. but right now that's all goals, which I do have. It's one day at a time .. and eventually I'll get there. 

My goals are (not in exact order): Move in to Dunham Hall (permanent SROs .. they're super cheap) once my GA is approved, finally start going to the doctor/dentist/gyno/etc. since I finally have the motivation again (and the insurance) start PHP at Princeton House, apply for SSI and SSDI, continue going to my meth clinic for weekly groups and monthly 1on1, appeal my financial aid so I can go back to MCCC for the Spring 15 semester for Communications, READ MORE BOOKS, PLAY ON MY PHONE LESS, when PHP is halfway done file family court motion to start visitation with my son again (it'll be 4 years in November that I haven't seen him due to my BPD), continue 1on1 therapy with a therapist once Princeton House is completed, transfer to Rutgers and major in Communication and minor in Social Work, MAYBE go for my Masters (unsure of that though, maybeee Social Work, maybe not .. we'll see, it'll be a Rutgers though). Find an awesome job, get off disability, get myself a car .. somewhere in there hopefully I'll finally get joint legal custody of my son again, and maybe find "the one. 

Sorry this was all over the place, not exactly what you guys, etc., but it's something, right? PLEASE, feel free to contact me. My # and email are listed below, but if for some reason it gets cut off: 6096589079 dana.mernone@yahoo.com. Hopefully we'll speak soon! I want to be able to help my peers like I'm helping myself .. they damn well know, even if it's deep deep down, they wanna have an awesome, heroin/drug free life.

name: Nancy
text: My 24 year old son is addicted to heroin, for the past 3 years now.   We do have insurance and even so, it has not always been an easy road to get him the treatment that he requires, detox and aftercare.   He has been in and out of rehab, just to come home and relapse again.    I am at my wits end, and truly am preparing myself for his incarceration or death.   To date, he is living in a sober living house .    I pray everyday for him as that's the only thing left I can do.    It's a heartbreaking disease, that affects everyone that loves him.

name: Juan
text: I've battled it since 2003 in nj. I lost friends and respect of my family. It was opiates I was addicted to. Always worrying. About my next fix and it was horrible. I started doing then due to a car accident where I broke my lower back. It was legally given to me due to the severity of the accident. Worked great for me in the beginning but somewhere along the way I became hooked. Now I battled the addiction until 3012. Once my father passed away and I came back to the states I reevaluated my life. Had no money or job and I felt worthless. In that moment of clarity I quit cold Turkey. It took about a year before the sudden cravings stopped. I was lucky though because I was able to do it on my own. Not many people have the will power to do so. I no longer live in jersey but my family is still there. I finished my bout with addiction in Florida.

name: Mary
text: My son is a recovering adult opiate pills that lead to heroin.  He didn't seak help till he got in legal trouble. Tried a 28 day program with insurance that still cost ud over 6 thousand dollars out of pocket.   Relapsed in 3 weeks 28 days is not enough and if you are in legal trouble you need permission to leave the state . This state has waiting lists. People dieing before they get treatment.  My son got permission to go to a long term christian program in NY state wanted to stay but couldn't because of probation. Thank God for his support network the Church an a group call Heroinkillsnj. I dont know where we would be.  It is sad you have to get arrested to get help and you can't leave the state that cant offer you help.

name: Christina
text: My mom was a heroin addict and it has forever changed my life in positive and negative ways. Due to her addiction she was unable to take care of my sister and I so we went to live with my grandma. She raised us as her own and I am forever thankful to have such a strong woman in my life who has been an amazing role model and helped me through confusing times while my mom was in and out of rehab. I managed to keep a relationship with my mom even though it was extremely rocky. After years of battling her addiction she became sober and eventually was 12 years clean. What once was a positive outcome, seeing my mom clean and living a functional life after such a hard battle, she eventually gave in. This past month I lost my mom due to a heroin over dose. It was a shock to my whole family and has forever changed my life. I never understood how hard addiction was until she passed away from an over dose. Clean or using this drug has a hold on the person and every day is a constant battle.

name: Matt
text:
I'm a suburban success story. My parents sound so proud when friends ask what I've done since college and they can smile and say Matt is a full time chemist making almost $70,000 a year at 24 years old. Compared to many kids I graduated with I'm doing better than most at least on the outside. I know that behind my mom's smile is a dark family secret that tears my parents apart and the worst part is that no matter what they do to help the heroin always seems to win. 

I grew up in an upper middle class family and never wanted for anything. I did everything your told to do, go to high school get good grades go to a good college graduate and get a job. Somewhere along that path I started working casual drug use into the mix and for years I refused to believe I had a problem because look at me "I just made the deans list i have a 3.7 GPA and I drive an audi. All of my "friends" love me but only a select few know what I struggle with. 

I started with painkillers which we thought were harmless because the older kids were taking them here and there and they were cheap if not free because kids would find them in their parents cabinets, bottles untouched for months. I went to college with a small pill habit almost relieved I was starting over in a new place and wouldn't be able to find drugs. I was wrong, I promise I wasn't even looking for them but they found me. 

I sold drugs in college to pay for my habit but the entire time I had myself convinced this is "normal." I watched kids get thrown out of school for partying too hard and never making it to class but considered my pill and drug use par for the course. I made it to 95% of my classes, aced tests I was the kid that other kids in the class wanted to study with. 

Soon the money became a major issue, I was spending like crazy and shortly after I was introduced to heroin. It was so cheap in the beginning the switch was a no brainer. For a long time I could days spending very little but slowly I needed more and more. I turned to the needle to reduce my use but addiction escalated faster than ever after that. 

I graduated with a 3.35 GPA and a double major in chemistry and biochemistry. I found a job shortly after and for the past 2 years I've been a full time salaried employee at a great company. None of my coworkers know my demons even though I'm high at work almost every day. 

I've been in programs IOP's and even a stint in inpatient. I have a great job and as much as I know I need help I'm so afraid to take medical leave from work because I'm afraid people will ask questions. 30 day leave? But Matt doesn't have any real medical problems. If they found out I'm afraid my job or at least the trust I've built would be destroyed. 

So i'm caught in a limbo I need treatment but I'm happy with my job. My parents worry everyday but I call them time to time and they must tell themselves I'm doing okay even though deep down they know thats not true. I wish I could turn back time. I remember days when I was happy and didn't need anything extra to help me along. I'm so used to this life now I don't know if I can ever stop.

name: Janice
text: Story is long, now probably four years and 15 rehabs into heroin addiction of my 22 year old son.  Nightmare, would love to share.  So much needs to be done.  I have insurance, but insurance doesn't ever want to pay for long term treatment.  Too many loop holes.  Many rehabs, and they all just want the insurance money.   Kids are young, dying, and never get the emotional treatment, or properly medicated before they move on to relapse, and yet another rehab.  Towns are in denial, kids are afraid of being killed by the dealers.  Trenton supplies our addicts in Hightstown and East Windsor.

text: My daughter has been to rehab 7 times now in the last 4 years. She's had at least 3 friends die already from heroin. They were only in their early 20s. We have to stop these drugs from being sold.

text: I was always that kid that said I would never do drugs and now I'm addicted to herion. I ran varsity track and cross country and high school and loved it. text: It all started when my son was hit by a car his friend was messing around with. His leg was broke and he ended up in a cast. Doctors gave him percoset. After he recovered, he till wanted the high of the percoset. I later learned from my son that heroin was alot cheaper and easier to get on the streets. That heroin, turned my son into someone we no longer knew. He stole from his grandmother, who he loved dearly and his parents and siblings. He tried the rehab, but it was because everyone convinced him to go. Not by his choice, so it was just a waste of time. He married and had 2 children and was finally straightening out. He got the soboxin and weened himself off with the help of this "tea" called Kratom. It helped alot for him. He stayed clean for almost a year, worked, paid off his fines and was 1 week way from going back home to florida with a license. I guess he decided to take that 1 last shot before going back home just for one last "thrill".....He never made it. His new address is Heaven

name: Kyle
text: Heroin brought me to my knees. It stripped me of my life. I was hopeless and could see no way out. My life had become all about getting one more. I thought there was no chance of me ever having a life. When I was finally broken enough, I sought help for myself and am now in recovery. There is hope, and we can recover. No matter what we have done in the past, we can live a life free from active addiction.

name: Kim
text:
I just thought I would share something I posted on Facebook in September for National Recovery Month:
Hello, my name is Kim. September is National Recovery Month. And in honor of that I'd like to be completely vulnerable and open to sharing my story. All I ask is that u keep an open mind while reading this. Up until about 2 years ago I was one of the many Americans who contributed to the ongoing stigma of addiction. If u were an addict you were a loser, scumbag, evil person, who just chose drugs instead of doing something better with your life. I hated drugs and to this day I still do. I lost a lot of friends do to their choices to due drugs and my choice not to. For awhile I started to feel like the only person in the area who didn't even smoke weed or enjoy drinking that much. I knew nothing about the disease of addiction. I had no clue it was a mental disease and it's not as simple as just putting the substance down. Until my world changed. In July of 2012 I met the sweetest, funniest, most caring guy. He is a hard worker. He has the biggest heart. Would give u the shirt off his back. Little did I know he was hiding a dark secret. He was a heroinaddict. He would become one of the many addicts/alcoholics in my life. Because addiction does not discriminate. It doesn't care how much money u have or how u were raised. It doesn't care how old u are or if your black, white, or purple. It takes the most caring and passionate people and turns them into things they would have never even dreamed themselves of becoming. But God blessed me with this special person. To open my eyes to how I judged so quickly and discriminated. And here I knew NOTHING about the struggle addicts go through.  The love of my life is one of the many people I know who struggles in their recovery. And it's the most heartbreaking thing in the world to watch. These people who I judged with disgust are someone's mom, dad, aunt, uncle, sister, brother, friend, husband, wife, cousin, co worker, daughter or son. And yet I thought I was better then them because I could pick up a drink or drug and my brain didn't tell me it needed that substance to function in everyday life?  Who was I kidding? As I started to educate myself I realized this had effected my life long before meeting my Boyfriend . And that is where I started my journey in changing my life. It's been a roller coaster of emotions. And learning so much about myself and the people I chose to surround myself with and the choices I made in life. I'm just as messed up as the next person. I just don't choose a substance to deal with my problems. But that doesn't make me better then them. We all have issues. I don't think we should throw stones or judge people until we have walked a day in their shoes. I now look at addiction with compassion and it literally breaks my heart to watch people struggle with this disease. And I support anyone who has the courage to recover from this disease. Because I know how much of a struggle it is. I watch it every single day in my daily life. We all know someone who suffers from addiction. And not everyone is willing to speak up about it because of the shame that comes with the stigma of addiction.  Not only is my bf judged for being an addict but I was also judged for staying by his side and I still am judged every single day.  I tell my story to build my own courage of being completely open and honest and also in hopes this changes at least one persons mind.  People do recover!

name: Lissette
text: I have a twin brother who is addicted to heroin. It has been a part of our lives (my family and I) for at least 8 years now, hard to believe that much time has gone by and we're still lucky enough to have him in our lives, even if it's the addicted side of him. We have been through a roller coaster ride from hell since we first became aware that he was using. Since then it's been the same repetitive cycle and jails and institutions missing death by the grace of god on a few occasions because multiple overdoses have occurred right in our own home. There's been lies and deceit, stealing from his own family, fight after fight and tears shed more than one can imagine, yet at the end of the day he is family and we love him just the same but we live with uncertainly day in and day and keep faith in hoping that tomorrow is another day that he awakens and maybe the day that he will become our brother/son/nephew/friend once again, the boy we all grew up loving, the boy who is no longer a boy but a man whom we don't even recognize anymore.
